DIVISION 2. - BEAUTIFICATION BOARD 

Sec. 2-236. - Created. 
    The beautification board of the city is constituted and created as an agency or board of the city. 
(Ord. No. 464, § 1, 9-24-85) 
Sec. 2-237. - Members. 
(a)  Two additional positions are hereby created on the Trussville Beautification Board, bringing the total membership of this body to seven. Board members shall be appointed by the City Council of the City of Trussville for a term of five years. The initial terms of these members shall be five years for one member and four years for the other. 
(b)  In the event of the death or resignation of any member of the beautification board, prior to the expiration of his term of service, the mayor and city council shall proceed forthwith to appoint a successor who shall serve out the unexpired term and shall enter upon his duties at the next regular meeting of the board. 
(Ord. No. 464, § 2, 9-24-85; Ord. No. 2006-022-ADM § 2, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 2-238. - Meetings; quorum. 
    Four members of the beautification board shall constitute a quorum for any meeting. The board shall set the date and time for regularly scheduled meetings, and all notice and meetings shall be conducted in accordance with the Alabama Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 464, § 4, 9-24-85; Ord. No. 2006-022-ADM, § 4, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 2-239. - Officers. 
    A chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary shall be elected by members of the beautification board at the first regular meeting at which a quorum is present after September 1 each year for a term of office to begin October 1 of that year and terminate on September 30 of the following year. 
(Ord. No. 464, § 5, 9-24-85) 
Sec. 2-240. - Function, advisory capacity, recommendations. 
(a)  The beautification board shall act in an advisory capacity to the mayor and city council in regard to the matters set out in this division. The board shall not have the right to sue or be sued or to have or to hold property, and all money or property accruing to it shall be vested in and be the money or property of the city. 
(b)  The beautification board shall study, investigate, develop and propose plans for improving the health, sanitation, safety and cleanliness of the city by beautifying the streets, highways, private property, alleys and other municipal properties. The board shall recommend such plans as it deems proper to the agencies of the city for the beautification of the city and otherwise promote public interest in the general improvement of the appearance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 464, § 3, 9-24-85) 
Secs. 2-241-2-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRUSSVILLE HISTORICAL BOARD[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Historical preservation authorities generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-10-135 et seq. 

Sec. 2-261. - Created; purposes. 
    There is created a board of the city to be known as the Trussville Historical Board, the principal purpose of which shall be to promote interest in the history of the city and to conduct projects and activities in connection therewith and to ensure the proper acknowledgment and recordation of events of historical significance for the information and benefit of future generations. 
(Ord. No. 232, § 1, 2-1-83) 
Sec. 2-262. - Members. 
    Two additional positions are hereby created on the Trussville Historical Board, bringing the total membership of this body to seven. Board members shall be appointed by the City Council of the City of Trussville for a term of four years. The initial terms of these two members shall be staggered in the following manner: one member shall be appointed for a term through April 5, 2007; and one member shall be appointed for a term through April 5, 2008. 
(Ord. No. 232, § 2, 2-1-83; Ord. No. 2005-001-ADM, § 1, 1-11-05) 
Sec. 2-263. - Organization; limitations; compensation. 
    The historical board shall be empowered to elect a chairperson, adopt bylaws, and transact such business as is necessary and appropriate to the attainment of its purposes, subject to any limitation provided by law. The historical board shall have no authority to bind the city by contract or otherwise without the express advance authorization from the city council. Board members shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 232, § 3, 2-1-83) 
Sec. 2-264. - Accountability, reports to council. 
    The historical board shall at all times be accountable to the city council for its receipts, expenditures and all aspects of its operation. The historical board shall report to the city council upon request of the council and, in any event, shall make a general report to the city council of its finances and activities not less than annually. 
(Ord. No. 232, § 4, 2-1-83) 
Secs. 2-265-2-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC SAFETY COMMITTEE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-006-PS, §§ 1-[7], adopted July 23, 2013, repealed former div. 4, §§ 2-281-2-284, and enacted a new div. 4 as set out herein. The former div. 4 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2005-002-ADM, §§ 1-4, adopted Jan. 12, 2005. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete derivation. 

Sec. 2-281. - [Membership and terms.] 
(a)  The advisory committee known as the Public Safety Committee of the City of Trussville, the purposes and objects of which shall include ongoing study of the operation of the public safety departments (police and fire departments) of the city, review and resolution, where possible, of public comments, complaints, and inquiries concerning the operation of the police and fire departments of the city, and making reports and recommendations to the city council as needed and requested with a view toward enhancing the efficiency, responsiveness, and morale of the police and fire departments, and public confidence therein. 
(b)  Increase public participation in disaster preparedness, using the resources of the public safety committee. Members of the committee shall directly work to organize increased public participation of those programs/events approved by the public safety committee. 
(c)  Provide a public forum for residents to share comments, issues or concerns regarding public safety issues, including but not limited to, crime prevention, community outreach and disaster preparedness education and training. 
(d)  The membership of the public safety committee shall be comprised of the Chief of Police of the City of Trussville, the Fire Chief of the City of Trussville, and five citizens of the City of Trussville. One of the citizens, if possible, shall serve as a representative of the business community of the city. One other citizen, if possible, will have a medial background or experience with emergency room and emergency life saving procedures. The mayor or his designee and city council liaison will be ex officio members and will not have a vote, but will only vote in case of a tie. One of the appointed citizen members will chair the meetings. 
(e)  Terms. The chief of police, fire chief, mayor and council liaison shall serve as long as they hold office. The term of the five citizen members will be staggered and will be for a duration of four years. Members may be reappointed at the expiration of their term or replaced, however if a reappointment or replacement does not occur timely, the incumbent member may continue to serve until reappointed or replaced. 
(f)  The public safety committee is authorized to organize itself so as to execute its functions efficiently and to adopt rules and procedures not inconsistent with its purposes and objectives hereinbefore set forth. The public safety committee is authorized, inter alia, to develop and recommend to the council for approval an administrative mechanism for reviewing public complaints and inquiries concerning the operation of the city police and fire departments. 
(g)  The public safety committee shall meet as needed or as it shall determine and shall, from time to time, report on its activities to the City Council of the City of Trussville. 
(Ord. No. 2013-006-PS, §§ 1-[7], 7-23-13; Ord. No. 2017-020-PS, §§ 1-7, 5-9-17) 
Secs. 2-282-2-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TREE COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-296. - Definitions. 
    City: "City" when referred to in this division shall mean the City of Trussville, Jefferson County, Alabama, and all persons, boards, and agencies acting in an official capacity for the city. 
    Trees: "Trees" are herein defined as large woody perennial plants at least 12 to 15 feet tall at maturity with one main trunk which develops many branches. This term shall include such classifications as shade trees, deciduous trees, coniferous trees and flowering trees. 
    Tree commission: "Tree commission" is herein defined as the five-member organization which is hereby established under this division. 
(Ord. No. 96-007 ADM, § 1, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 2-297. - Creation and establishment. 
    There is hereby created and established a tree commission for the city, which shall consist of five members. Members shall be citizens and residents of the city, and shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 96-007 ADM, § 2, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 2-298. - Term of office. 
    The term of office for the five commissioners to be appointed by the mayor shall be three years, except that the term of two of the commissioners appointed to the first commissioners of the first commission shall be for two years only. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Ord. No. 96-007 ADM, § 3, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 2-299. - Compensation. 
    Members of the commission shall serve without compensation, and their participation will be considered as voluntary public service to the community. 
(Ord. No. 96-007 ADM, § 4, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 2-300. - Scope of authority. 
    The Trussville Tree Commission shall have authority to address and make recommendations to the city on all issues pertaining to trees located in public parks, recreation areas, within public right-of-ways, and in other public areas under the ownership and/or management of the city. The tree commission's scope of authority shall extend to trees located on private lands when necessary to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, and maintain the environmental and aesthetic quality of the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-007 ADM, § 5, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 2-301. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the Trussville Tree Commission shall be as follows: 
(1)  The tree commission shall make studies, investigate, counsel, develop and administer written and/or graphic plans for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal and disposal of trees within the scope of it's authority. 
(2)  Plans and recommendations prepared by the tree commission shall be presented annually to the city council, and upon their acceptance and approval, shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the city. 
(3)  The tree commission shall assist the city in developing a yearly budget for implementing the plans and recommendations in phases, and establishing priorities for expenditures. 
(4)  The tree commission shall develop policies and ordinances for the care, preservation, and planting of trees lying within the scope of its authority, and recommend the adoption of such policies and ordinances to the city council and/or city planning and zoning board. 
(5)  The tree commission, when requested by the city, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report, and recommend upon any special matter or question falling within the scope of its authority. 
(Ord. No. 96-007 ADM, § 6, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 2-302. - Operation. 
    The Trussville Tree Commission shall hold meetings for the purpose of conducting its business as deemed necessary by its commissioners, with a minimum of one such meeting per quarter. 
    The tree commission will prepare and submit to the city council a report summarizing its activities at the end of each quarter of the city's fiscal year. 
    The tree commission shall choose it's own officers, make it's own rules and regulations, and keep a journal of it's proceedings. A majority of the commissioners shall be considered a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 96-007 ADM, § 7, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 2-303. - Review by the city council. 
    The Trussville City Council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts, and decisions of the tree commission. Any person affected by the plans, recommendations, or policies proposed or established by the tree commission may appeal to the city council, who may conduct a hearing on the matter and render a final decision. 
(Ord. No. 96-007 ADM, § 8, 2-27-96) 
Secs. 2-304-2-314. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SENIOR CITIZENS' ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-315. - Purpose. 
    A senior citizens' advisory board shall be established as a recommending body to the city council. The responsibilities of this board shall include, but not be limited to, establishing guidelines for the use of the senior citizens' activity center and making recommendations as to what is needed or desirable to make the building suitable for activities. Further, this board shall make recommendations for formulating programs to meet the needs of this group, be it through cooperative interaction with other senior citizens' groups, social events, travel, recreation, crafts and artistic endeavors, speakers, education, mentoring, or offering the unbounded resource of the vast accumulation of knowledge within this group that can be shared among the membership, within the public school system, or to the community at large. In addition, this board shall also address health and welfare issues of the senior population and make recommendations as to how these needs can better be met by the community. The duties of this board shall be ongoing. It will study the effectiveness of the facility and its programming and review the operation to ensure the elements provided meet the demands of the group it serves, and further, shall report these findings to the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-008-ADM, § 1, 5-11-99) 
Sec. 2-316. - Members. 
    The membership of the senior citizens' advisory board shall consist of eight senior citizens who live within the corporate limits of the city and actively participate in seniors' activities. Appointments shall be made by the city council as a whole. The council person over parks and recreation and a member of the Jefferson County Commission or their designee shall serve as liaisons to the board, but will not have a vote. Members may be removed for cause by the mayor. Further, any member missing four consecutive monthly meetings may be removed by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 99-008-ADM, § 2, 5-11-99; Ord. No. 2002-056-P+R, § 1, 11-27-02) 
Sec. 2-317. - Terms. 
(a)  Terms. The terms of service shall be for four-year periods. The original terms shall be staggered as follows: 
One additional position shall expire April 14, 2004; 
One additional position shall expire April 14, 2005. 
(b)  [Council liaison.] The term of the council liaison shall coincide with his or her term of office. Vacancies occurring before the expiration of the term will be filled as soon as is practical, without changing the original expiration. Members may be reappointed. 
(Ord. No. 99-008-ADM, § 3, 5-11-99; Ord. No. 2002-056-P+R, § 2, 11-27-02) 
Sec. 2-318. - Organization and meetings. 
    The senior citizens' advisory board herein established shall be authorized to organize itself so as to execute its functions efficiently and to adopt rules and procedures consistent with its purposes and objectives as set out, or as may evolve due to changing conditions or changing needs of the group it serves. The board shall elect from among its membership a chairperson and a vice-chairperson who shall preside in the absence of the chairperson. A secretary shall be appointed from the membership to keep minutes to record the actions and recommendations of this board. The board shall meet monthly on a specific day and time to be determined by the members. 
(Ord. No. 99-008-ADM, § 4, 5-11-99) 
Secs. 2-319-2-324. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - DESIGN REVIEW COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-325. - Purpose. 
    A design review committee shall be established as an advisory body to review all construction proposals in any commercial, industrial, institutional, multifamily, historic district, or residential subdivision entrances and common areas, and for any public facilities. The committee shall review construction plans for proposed structure(s), plans for the redevelopment of any existing structure(s), signage, landscape, and lighting in any of the enumerated districts within the city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction. The responsibilities of this committee shall include, but not be limited to, review of architectural plans, to develop architectural standards and design guidelines, to develop rules and regulations for the review of development standards and ensuring compliance with those guidelines, and to make recommendations to the appropriate city body or department for the implementation of development standards. Further, this design review committee shall advise upon and recommend to owners and developers how to comply with the committee guidelines and how to develop projects to promote compatibility and conformity with surrounding uses and applicable design standards. The duties of this committee shall be ongoing. It shall report all findings and recommendations in writing to the appropriate city board or department. 
(Ord. No. 2005-25-ADM, § 1, 6-14-05; Ord. No. 2005-048-ADM, § 1, 9-27-05) 
Sec. 2-326. - Members. 
    The design review committee shall consist of six voting members who live within the corporate limits of the City of Trussville and shall be comprised of three citizen members, one member of the city council, and one member of the planning and zoning board, and one member of the redevelopment authority, each of whom shall serve without additional compensation. Appointments shall be made by the city council as a whole. In addition to these five members, the chief building official or his/her designee shall serve in an advisory capacity. Members may be removed for cause by the city council. Further, any member missing four consecutive monthly meetings may be removed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2005-025-ADM, § 2, 6-14-05; Ord. No. 2015-019-ADM, § 1(2), 8-11-15) 
Sec. 2-327. - Terms. 
    The terms of service for citizen members shall be for three-year periods, while the terms of the city council member, the planning and zoning board member, and the redevelopment authority member shall run with their respective terms. The original terms of citizen members shall be staggered as follows: 
One shall expire August 23, 2006; 
One shall expire August 23, 2007; 
One shall expire August 23, 2008. 
    Vacancies occurring before the expiration of the term will be filled as soon as is practical, without changing the respective expiration date of that vacant term of citizen members. Members may be reappointed. 
(Ord. No. 2005-025-ADM, § 3, 6-14-05; Ord. No. 2015-019-ADM, § 2(3), 8-11-15) 
Sec. 2-328. - Organization and meetings. 
    The architectural review committee herein established shall be authorized to organize itself so as to execute its functions efficiently and to adopt rules and procedures consistent with its purposes and objectives as set out, or as may evolve due to changing conditions or changing needs of the community. All meetings shall be conducted in compliance with the provisions of the Alabama Open Meetings Law. The board shall elect from among its membership a chairperson and a vice-chairperson who shall preside in the absence of the chairperson. A secretary shall be appointed from the membership to keep minutes to record the actions and recommendations of this committee. The committee shall meet monthly on a specific day and time to be determined by the members, but prior to the deadline for submissions to the planning and zoning board. A monthly meeting shall not be required if there are no pending items for review submitted by the submittal cutoff date to be established by the committee. 
(Ord. No. 2005-025-ADM, § 4, 6-14-05) 
Secs. 2-329-2-340. - Reserved. 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 58. 
State Law reference- Intoxicating liquor, malt beverages and wine generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Public consumption. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume or drink any intoxicating beverage in any public place other than on the premises where purchased and on which a license has been procured by the proprietor thereof for the sale and consumption of that particular type of beverage. 
(Ord. No. 174, § 18, 7-12-77; Ord. No. 95-038 MC, 11-14-96) 
Sec. 6-2. - Failure to appear on charge of driving under the influence. 
    A person commits the violation of failure to appear on the charge of driving under the influence if, having been lawfully released from custody, with or without bail, upon the condition that he will subsequently appear at the specified time and place in connection with either: 
A charge of violation of Ordinance 236 which encompasses Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191(a)(1); 
A charge of violation of Ordinance 236 which encompasses Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191(a)(2); 
A charge of violation of Ordinance 236 which encompasses Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191(a)(3); 
A charge of violation of Ordinance 236 which encompasses Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191(a)(4); 
all of which are more commonly known as driving under the influence, if he fails to appear at that time and place. 
    It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the defendant's failure to appear was unintentional or unavoidable and due to circumstances beyond his control. The burden of injecting the defense of an unintentional failure to appear, or unavoidability and circumstances beyond his control, is on the defendant. 
(Ord. No. 95-037 MC, §§ 1, 2, 11-14-95) 
Secs. 6-3-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, §§ I-XIX, adopted June 13, 1995, amended §§ 6-31-6-48 to read as herein set out. Formerly, such sections pertained to similar provisions and derived from Ord. No. 95-001 ADM, §§ I-XIX, adopted Jan. 24, 1995. 

Sec. 6-31. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Trussville Alcoholic Beverage Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § I, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-32. - Purpose. 
    This article is enacted for the purposes, among others, of promoting the health and general welfare of the community, of establishing reasonable standards for the regulation and control of the licensing and sales of alcoholic beverages, and of protecting and preserving certain areas, through reasonable consideration, among others, to the character of the areas and their peculiar suitability for particular uses, to the congestion in the roads and streets, to a general view of promoting desirable living conditions and sustaining stability of neighborhoods and property values, and to the prevention of undesirable persons from engaging in or having any interest in alcoholic beverages. This article shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the city. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § I, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-33. - Definitions. 
    Wherever used in this article, and except as the context otherwise clearly requires, the definitions set forth in the Code of Ala. 1975, § 28-3-1 et seq., as amended from time to time, are adopted by reference, and made a part of this article as if fully set forth in this article. In addition thereto, the following terms shall have the meanings specifically ascribed to them: 
    Church means any permanent building located within the corporate city limits of the city where persons regularly assemble for religious worship. The building shall be publicly designated as a church, but shall not include a residence also used for religious purposes. For purposes of this article, leased or rented space zoned commercially will not be considered a church regardless of the use of the leased or rented space. For purposes of this article, a chapel or any room used for religious purposes and called by any name within a nursing home, retirement home, hospital, medical clinic, funeral home or cemetery shall not be considered a church. 
    Distance means the measure in linear feet from the center of the nearest door of the proposed licensed premises to the center of the nearest door of a school, church or library. 
    Grocery store means a retail establishment whose primary function is the sale of packaged or unprepared food and grocery items for consumption off the premises and whose annual gross sales of alcoholic beverages do not exceed five percent of its total gross sales from all sources as evidenced by a certified audit showing the sales for a calendar year most recently ending at the proposed location for a similar store at a similar location. For the purposes of this article, retail establishments selling gasoline shall not be considered grocery stores. 
    Library means a facility that is open to the public for the purpose of maintaining books, periodicals and other material for use by the public. Such facility shall be managed by a librarian who is a full-time employee of the city. 
    License means a lounge retail liquor license, a club retail liquor license, a restaurant retail liquor license or other license issued by the state alcoholic beverage board requiring consent and approval of the city council. 
    Restaurant means a reputable place licensed as a restaurant, operated by a responsible person of good reputation, and habitually and principally kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are actually and regularly served with at least 1,000 square feet of dining space and equipped with tables and chairs to accommodate at least 50 people at one time. Such place shall be provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment, air conditioned and heated as appropriate, having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. At least one meal per day shall be served at least five days per week, with the exception of holidays, vacations and periods of redecorating, and the serving of such meals shall be the principal business conducted, with the serving of alcoholic beverages to be consumed on the premises as only incidental thereto. 
    School means a state accredited grammar, elementary, middle, junior high or senior high school. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § III, 6-13-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 6-34. - Application required. 
(a)  Each applicant seeking the consent and approval of the city council for a license issued by the state alcoholic beverage control board shall make application to the city council as required in this article. 
(b)  The application shall be upon an appropriate form supplied by the city clerk. 
(c)  The application shall be fully completed. No application will be accepted by the city clerk unless fully completed. All spaces must have a response. 
(d)  The application and all supporting documentation must be submitted with the original and three copies. Copies must be made prior to filing the application with the clerk. No copies will be made in any municipal building for or on behalf of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § IV, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-35. - Contents of application. 
(a)  An application seeking the consent and the approval of the city council for a license shall contain the following information and statements: 
(1)  The name and residence of the applicant and how long he has resided in the indicated place, and if a partnership, association, unincorporated enterprise or corporation, the names and residences of the partners, members, officers and directors, and how long each of such persons has resided at the indicated place. 
(2)  A description of the particular place for which the license is desired, and a description or plan of that part of the lounge, club, hotel, restaurant, civic center or dinner theater where it is proposed to keep and sell alcoholic beverages. 
(3)  The date and place of birth of the applicant, and if a naturalized citizen, when and where naturalized; if a corporation, when and where incorporated, and if not incorporated in the state, then whether or not it is duly qualified under the laws of the state to do business in the state. If a corporation, the application shall also contain a statement that all officers and directors of the corporation are reputable individuals and are citizens of the United States, and the further statement that at least 51 percent of the capital stock is actually owned by individuals who are citizens of the United States. 
(4)  The name(s) and address(es) of the owner or owners of the premises upon which the business is to be conducted, together with the names and addresses of all lessees and sublessees. A copy of any lease agreement under which the applicant has the right of possession, if the applicant is not the owner of the property, shall be filed as an attachment to the application. The certification of the application shall include the certification of the lease agreement; provided, however, that the amount of monthly rental or other compensation to be paid by the lessee under the lease may be struck out on the attached copy. 
(5)  That the applicant is not, or in the case of a partnership, association or unincorporated enterprise, that the partners or members are not, and in the case of a corporation, that the officers and directors are not, in any manner pecuniarily interested either directly or indirectly in the profits in any other class of business regulated under this article and/or the alcoholic beverage licensing code of the state, or if so interested, the extent of the interest, including name of such business, must be stated. 
(6)  That the applicant is the only person in any manner pecuniarily interested in the business so asked to be licensed, except as stated, and that no other person shall be in any manner pecuniarily interested therein during the continuance of the license. 
(7)  Whether the applicant, or in the case of a partnership, association or unincorporated enterprise, any partner or member thereof, or in the case of a corporation, any officer, director or stockholder thereof, has, during the three years immediately preceding the date of the application, had a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages revoked or suspended by any governmental authority. 
(8)  A statement whether the applicant has made application heretofore for a similar or other liquor license, and the disposition of such application. 
(9)  A statement showing the criminal records of the applicant, each partner, member, officer, member of board of directors, landlord and manager and shall include every violation charged irrespective of disposition of each charge. Minor traffic offenses may be omitted; however, driving while intoxicated and reckless driving cases must be shown. 
(10)  Plans and renderings of the proposed premises. 
(11)  A scale drawing of the location of the proposed premises and the distance therefrom to the nearest door of any school, church, or library, the accuracy of which is certified by a registered surveyor, may be required from the applicant when deemed necessary by the city to determine the applicability of section 6-41(4) hereof, which section establishes certain distance restrictions and exceptions thereto. 
(12)  The application must be signed and verified by oath or affirmation by the owner, partner or officer depending on type of entity making the application. 
(b)  Each applicant for a club retail liquor license shall also file with, and as part of, the application, the following: 
(1)  A certified copy of the certificate of incorporation, and of the constitution and bylaws of the club. 
(2)  A verified list of the paid-up members of the club at the time of application, together with the resident address of each paid-up member. 
(3)  The name and residence address of the manager of the club. If the person shown as manager of the club ceases to be the manager, then the club shall notify the city clerk within five days of such change, together with the name and resident address of any new manager. 
(4)  A copy of any certificate from the Internal Revenue Service or Treasury Department concerning any exemption of the club from taxation. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § V, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-36. - City clerk to receive application. 
(a)  The application along with all supporting paperwork shall be filed with the city clerk. The city clerk shall not accept the application until all fees are paid by the applicant. The fees are to be set by the city council as a processing fee to cover the expense of advertising, investigation and processing of the application and the fee is not refundable. 
(b)  The city clerk shall immediately deliver copies of the application to the police chief, building inspector and finance officer. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § VI, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-37. - Investigation. 
(a)  Investigation by police department. The police chief or his designated officer shall conduct a background investigation of all applicants for a license. The investigation shall include: 
(1)  The following indices checks: 
a.  Trussville Police Department. 
b.  Jefferson County Sheriff's Office. 
c.  NCIC and ACJIS. 
(2)  If the applicant has an existing business, then the police department in that municipality of the business and the sheriff's office that has jurisdiction should be consulted for criminal history checks as well as incidents, arrests and calls for service at the existing business. 
(3)  All other aspects of the application that the police chief deems useful in assisting the city council to render a decision. 
(b)  Investigation by city building inspector. The building inspector shall conduct an investigation that will include: 
(1)  An inspection of the proposed building if it exists at the time of application to see that all code requirements are met. If there is no existing building, then a review of the plans. 
(2)  Consultation with the fire inspector to see that the fire code is complied with and there are no hazards. 
(3)  A check to ensure that the property is zoned properly. 
(4)  All other aspects of the application that the building inspector deems useful in assisting the city council to render a decision. 
(c)  Investigation by finance officer. 
(1)  The city treasurer or a designated finance officer shall investigate the applicant with regard to business licenses, taxes and tax returns and other forms filed in the city or any other municipality where the applicant has or currently does business. 
(2)  All other aspects of the application the finance officer deems useful in assisting the city council to render a decision. 
(d)  Investigation by city clerk. The city clerk shall assemble a list of all property owners, if known, or occupants, if property owners are unknown, located within 750 feet of the proposed licensed premises, which information shall be used for the purpose of providing notice of public hearing hereinafter described. 
(e)  Investigation results. The chief of police, building inspector and finance officer shall submit the application, together with the results of the investigations and recommendations thereon, back to the city clerk who shall submit it to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § I, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-38. - Producing persons for oral interrogation. 
    Applicants by filing an application agree to produce for oral interrogation any person(s) requested by the city council, when deemed necessary to ascertain facts relative to the license application. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § I, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-39. - Time limit for city to process application. 
    The city must conduct their investigation and furnish the complete report to the city council within 45 days of receipt of the license application. The city council may shorten or extend the time for the investigation as deemed appropriate under the circumstances. The city council shall act on the application within 30 days of receiving the results of the completed investigation. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § I, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-40. - Public notices, intent of hearing. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application, together with the results of the investigation and recommendations made thereon, the city clerk shall cause notice to be published two times in a newspaper of general circulation published in the county, stating that the application will be considered at the next regular meeting of the city council, which said notice must be published as aforesaid two times at least six days in advance of the next regular meeting of the city council, and further stating the time and place that it is to be considered and that at such time and place all interested persons shall have an opportunity of being heard in opposition to or in favor of the application. Such publication shall be at the applicant's expense and must be paid prior to action by the city council. 
(b)  The city clerk shall mail written notice of the application, stating the day and time the application is to be heard and considered, to all property owners, if known, or occupants, if property owners are unknown, located within 750 feet of the proposed licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § X, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-41. - Action by city council. 
    In rendering a decision on each application, the city council shall consider, among others, the following factors: 
(1)  The investigations and recommendations of the police chief, building inspector and finance officer. 
(2)  The application, applicant's compliance with the application process and the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city. 
(3)  The location of the proposed establishment to include effects upon residents, businesses, traffic flow and congestion. 
(4)  No license shall be approved by the city council when the distance between the premises to be licensed and a school, church or library is less than 750 feet; provided, however, that the aforesaid distance restrictions shall not apply in the following enumerated cases: 
a.  Where the licensed premises are separated from the church, school or library by a street or highway having four or more traffic lanes; 
b.  Where the licensed premises is a grocery store; 
c.  Where the licensed premises is a restaurant as defined herein; or 
d.  Where the church, school or library was established after the licensed premises began operation and the operation has not been abandoned or discontinued for a period of six months. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § I, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-42. - Duty of management of licensed premises. 
    It shall be the duty of each owner and of each manager or supervisor at any time charged with the management and supervision of any licensed premises, while the same is open to the public, to maintain order upon the premises and to exclude from the premises any person who is drunk and disorderly or who commits any breach of the peace, or who uses offensive, disorderly, threatening, abusive or insulting language, conduct or behavior with the intent to provoke a breach of the peace, or whereby a breach of the peace might be occasioned. It shall be the duty of each officer, owner, manager or person in charge of any licensed premises within the city immediately to make an appropriate report to the police department of the city of each assault, assault and battery or affray occurring on the licensed premises while the premises are open for business. It shall further be the duty of such person to make a written report of each of the incidents to the police department of the city and to the local field office of the state alcoholic beverage control board within 36 hours thereof. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § I, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-43. - Unlawful consumption and dispensing. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink, sell, serve, dispense or give away or attempt to drink, sell, serve, dispense or give away, any alcoholic beverages, while upon any street, alley or in any public building or upon any public property, or while in any other public place in the city. As used in this section, the term "public place" shall mean and include any place or gathering which the public generally attends or is admitted to, either by invitation, common consent or right, or by the payment of an admission or other charge, and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, shall include public parks, city hall, library, school buildings, school grounds, playgrounds, auditoriums, any store or place where merchandise of any kind is offered for sale, any theater or other place of amusement and any athletic contest or the premises upon which any such building is located; provided, that such term shall not mean or include premises which have been duly licensed by the city for sale thereon of such beverages. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a church using wine for religious services. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § I, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-44. - Prohibited persons. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or for any employee, servant or agent of any person to sell, or offer for sale, any alcoholic beverages to any person visibly intoxicated, or to any insane person, or to any minor, or to any habitual drunkard. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to serve to a minor or allow a minor to be served any alcoholic beverage in any place where such beverages are sold. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person who operates any business of selling alcoholic beverages to allow any alcoholic beverages to be sold to any minor, or to be consumed by any minor on the premises where such alcoholic beverages are sold. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to a church using wine for religious services. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § I, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-45. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to do or perform any of the acts or things designated as follows: 
(1)  For any minor person (i.e., for the purposes of this article, any person under the legal drinking age as established by or for the state), directly or indirectly, to purchase any alcoholic beverage, or to attempt to purchase any alcoholic beverage. 
(2)  For any minor person to possess or to consume any alcoholic beverages in any public place, or in any business establishment or club. 
(3)  For any person to sell, furnish, give to or purchase for any minor person, any alcoholic beverages, any wine or liquor or any alcoholic or intoxicating beverage, or to attempt to sell, furnish, give to or purchase for any person under the legal drinking age, any alcoholic beverages. It shall be the absolute responsibility for the dispenser of such beverages to determine that the person receiving same is above the legal drinking age. 
(4)  For any person to hire, employ or allow any minor person to serve or dispense alcoholic beverages. 
(5)  For any minor person, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent that such person is not a minor or is not under the legal drinking age as established by or for the state, by means of which false representation such person buys, receives or otherwise obtains, or attempts to buy, receive or otherwise obtain any alcoholic beverages. 
(6)  For any person, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent or attempt to falsely represent that a minor person is not a minor or is not under the legal drinking age as established by or for the state, by which false representation such person aids or abets, or attempts to aid or abet such minor person to buy, receive or otherwise obtain any alcoholic beverages. 
(7)  To possess any container of alcoholic beverages in any motor vehicle which the individual container has been opened or has had the seal therefrom broken. 
(8)  To possess, consume, sell, dispense, give away or to allow the possession, consumption, sale, dispensing, or giving away of any alcoholic beverage in any game room open to the public or operated by any club as enumerated herein containing any electronic games of any description. 
This subsection shall not apply to a church using wine for religious services. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, club, firm, or corporation or the officers, members, agents, servants or persons in charge thereof at any club or at any other place to which the public generally resorts or is admitted, which is either a liquor, wine or beer licensed place, or any combination thereof, to permit, allow, conduct or condone any of the following: 
(1)  Topless or bottomless waitresses, dancers or performers, or any lewd or indecent conduct. 
(2)  Acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law. 
(3)  Acts or simulated acts of caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
(4)  Acts involving the displaying of the anus, vulva or genitals. 
(5)  Permitting any patron, customer or member to touch, caress or fondle the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals or any part of the body or clothing of a performer. 
(6)  Permitting the showing of films, still pictures, electronic reproduction or other visual reproductions depicting: 
a.  Acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law. 
b.  Any person being touched, caressed or fondled on the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
c.  Scenes wherein a person displays the vulva or the anus or the genitals. 
d.  Scenes wherein artificial devices or inanimate objects are employed to depict, or drawings are employed to portray, any of the prohibited activities described above. 
(7)  Wet T-shirt contests, wrestling or mud wrestling or fist fights or any display of the martial arts. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, §§ XV, XVI, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-46. - License required. 
    No alcoholic beverages shall be manufactured, sold at wholesale or retail or possessed for the purpose of sale, except under a license granted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § XVII, 6-13-95) 
Cross reference- City council, § 2-26 et seq. 
Sec. 6-47. - License a privilege. 
(a)  All licenses shall be a mere grant or privilege to carry on such business during the term of the license subject to all the terms and conditions imposed by this article and related laws and other ordinances and resolutions by the city relating to such business. 
(b)  All licenses under this article shall have stamped or printed on the front these words: "This license is a mere privilege subject to be revoked and annulled by the mayor and council of the City of Trussville." 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § XVIII, 6-13-95) 
Sec. 6-48. - Penalty. 
    Failure to comply with the terms and provisions of this article shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this article. Any person or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00. In addition thereto, any person so convicted may be imprisoned or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding six months. 
(Ord. No. 95-28 ADM, § XIX, 6-13-95) 
Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1]
