Secs. 10-26-10-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ANIMAL CONTROL 

Sec. 10-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandonment or setting loose to avoid responsibility. Shall include, but not be limited to, leaving the animal to fend for itself, deserting, or putting out the animal without accepting responsibility for the animal's actions. 
    Animal. Any organism of the kingdom Animalia other than a human being, including, but not limited to, mammals, fish, birds and reptiles. 
    Bird. Any warm blooded vertebrate of the class aves that has a body covered with feathers and forelimbs modified into wings. 
    Canine corps dogs. Dogs maintained by governmental agencies for exclusive use in official duties assigned to those agencies. 
    Cat. Any member of the domestic feline family. 
    City. Within the corporate limits of the City of Trussville. 
    City pound, impoundment center, or rabies control center. The place so designated by the city or by the county board of health, or such other person with whom the city may contract for the maintenance or operation of a city pound, whether such city pound is located within the limits of the city or elsewhere in the county. 
    Companion animal. Dog trained to function as a companion animal for the disabled, including but not limited to seeing eye dogs. 
    Dog. Any member of the domestic canine family. 
    Domestic animal. Any animal that is tame and is taken care of by an individual, petted and fed, and that has been in the presence of humans. 
    Effective restraint. Restrained by fence, cage, glass, mesh enclosure, leash or other restraining device in the hands of such owner or other person of sufficient age who shall possess sufficient physical capabilities and the ability to maintain complete control of said animal, or within the confines of the owner's property or the property of the person in charge of said animal. 
    Exotic animal. An animal which would ordinarily be confined to a zoo or found in a wilderness area of any country; an animal or species of animal not indigenous to North America; and an animal which would cause a reasonable person to be fearful of significant loss of property or bodily harm. 
    Exotic animals include, but are not limited to, raccoons, bobcats, coyotes, wolves, hybrid wolves, Vietnamese pot bellied pigs, monkeys, or other such animals. This definition shall not include animals customarily used in Alabama as domestic farm animals, fish confined in an aquarium, birds or insects. 
    Fowl. A domestic bird used in the market or household for food consumption, such as a chicken, duck, goose, guinea, peafowl, turkey, pheasant, pigeon, ostrich, or other avian species. 
    Nuisance animal. An animal that threatens the safety of or damages a member of the general public or interferes with the ordinary use and enjoyment of another's property. 
    Owner. A person having a right of property in the animal or having charge, control, possession, or dominion over said animal. Owner shall be construed to include any person, partnership, corporation, or other legal entity. 
    Public nuisance. Any animal or any condition resulting from an animal that unreasonably annoys human beings, endangers the lives or health of other animals or persons or substantially interferes with the rights of citizens, other than its owners, to enjoyment of life or property. 
    Run at large. Shall include all times and places when the animal is not confined or enclosed within a wall, fence, or other enclosure (to include electronic fences) on the premises of the animal's owner or person in charge of the animal, or under the direct supervision of the owner or person in charge of the animal within the confinement of the yard, where the legal residence is that of the owner or the person in charge of the animal. An animal off leash within the confines of a sanctioned dog park shall not be deemed to be running at large. 
    Stray animal. Any animal running at large, the owner of which is unknown. 
    Vicious animal. Any animal with a known propensity, tendency, or disposition to attack unprovoked, to chase moving vehicles, to charge persons in public areas, to cause injury to, or to otherwise endanger the safety of humans or other domestic animals or any animal which attacks a human being or other domestic animal without provocation, whether or not such animal has actually bitten or attacked a person or other domestic animal. 
(Ord. No. 98-013 ADM, § 1, 4-14-98; Ord. No. 2017-027-ADM, § 1, 5-23-17) 
Sec. 10-52. - General prohibitions and duties. 
(1)  Public nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, possess or maintain an animal in such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance, as defined by this article and state law. 
By way of example, and not of limitation, the following acts or actions by an owner of an animal are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and are therefore unlawful: 
a.  Allowing or permitting an animal to damage the property of anyone other than its owner, including, but not limited to, getting into or turning over garbage containers, or damaging gardens, flowers and vegetables, or defecating upon the property of another. 
b.  Maintaining an animal in an unsanitary environment that results in offensive odors or is dangerous to the animal or to the public health, safety and welfare, or failing to maintain the animal in a condition of good order and cleanliness which increases the probability of disease transmission. 
c.  Maintaining the owner's property in a manner that is offensive, annoying, or dangerous to the public health, safety, or welfare of the community because of the number, type, variety, density, or location of animals on the property. 
d.  Allowing or permitting an animal to bark, whine, howl, crow, or cackle in an excessive and untimely fashion so as to interfere with the reasonable use and enjoyment of neighboring premises. 
e.  Maintaining an animal that is diseased or dangerous to the public health. 
f.  Maintaining an animal that habitually or repeatedly chases, snaps at, or attacks pedestrians, joggers, animals walked on a leash by owners, bicycles, or other vehicles, unless such animal is under effective restraint. 
(2)  General prohibitions and duties-Running at large. No owner or any person having charge of control of an animal shall cause or permit such animal to run or be upon a street, sidewalk, thoroughfare, alley or public place within the city unless such animal be attached to a leash in the hands of such owner or other person in charge, or be restrained by other control device; provided however, that such owner or person in charge be of sufficient age, training, and physical capabilities to maintain complete control of said animal. 
(3)  Abandonment. No person shall abandon or set loose any domestic animal within the city with the intention of avoiding the responsibility for the custody or care of that animal. 
(4)  Causing escape. No owner or other person shall take an animal from the confinement or restraint of its owner or of the person in charge or control of it or cause an animal to escape from such confinement or restraint without specific permission from the owner or person in charge or control of the animal. 
(5)  Cruelty to animals. The following shall constitute violations of this article and shall be strictly prohibited: 
a.  Failing to provide adequate food or water for any animal, provided such person is the owner or person in charge of such animal. 
b.  Overworking or overloading any animal in a manner which causes physical pain and suffering. 
c.  Beating, torturing, injuring, tormenting, poisoning, depriving of necessary sustenance, or mutilating any animal in a manner which causes pain, suffering, or death. 
d.  Failing to provide adequate medical attention for any sick, diseased, or injured animal, provided such person is the owner or person in charge of such animal. 
e.  Keeping any animal under unsanitary and inhumane conditions or in unsanitary or inhumane conditions that are detrimental to the animal's health and general welfare. 
f.  Teasing, molesting, or harassing any animal. 
g.  Setting any rabbit, raccoon, fox or other such animal loose for the purpose of chasing or hunting the animal, or conducting a race using such animal. 
h.  Promoting, permitting, holding, managing, conducting, allowing, or attending any fight or combat between one or more animals or fowls, or between animals and humans. 
i.  Failing to provide adequate shelter for an animal, provided such person is the owner or person in charge of such animal. 
j.  Placing or confining an animal or allowing an animal to be placed or confined in a motor vehicle under such conditions or for such a period of time as to endanger the health or welfare of the animal because of temperature, lack of food or water, or such other conditions as may reasonably be expected to cause suffering, disability, or death. 
k.  Restraining an animal with a leash or other restraining device that is less than eight feet long, unless walking or training such animal. 
Any person who unlawfully or maliciously kills, disables, disfigures, or injures any animal shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, but this section shall not be construed as prohibiting the dehorning of cattle. 
(6)  Keeping of hogs. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep hogs within the city, except in areas zoned for agricultural use, and under circumstances where no noise, odor, or pollution violation or nuisance is occasioned thereby, and at a place more than 300 feet from any neighboring residence, business, house, church, or school yard, and at a place more than 100 feet from any road, street, or other thoroughfare. 
b.  All hogs in transit or housed or penned for sale at a duly authorized marketing place within the city shall be removed by sale, slaughtering, or otherwise within eight days. All pens or enclosures wherein said hogs are kept shall have concrete floors with ample drains and water connections, as approved by the health department. Said pens and enclosures shall be cleaned daily with suitable insecticides or deodorants, or both, as approved by the health department, so that fly control is satisfactorily maintained. 
(7)  Noisy animals. 
a.  It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to keep on any tract, lot, or premises within the city any animal or group of animals known to said person to habitually or continuously emit sounds or noises of such volume and nature as to unreasonably interfere with or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort, and repose of persons of ordinary sensibilities within the neighborhood in the reasonable use and enjoyment of any residential property. 
b.  Any owner or person in charge who is found in violation of this section shall be guilty of maintaining a nuisance; provided, however, that no prosecution shall be commenced pursuant to this subsection nor any summons and complaint or warrant issued except upon affidavits of no less than three persons residing in or occupying different premises in the area where the violation occurred. Said affidavits shall be sworn to and subscribed before the magistrate of the city. 
(8)  Keeping wild, vicious, exotic mammals, fowl or reptiles. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any owner or person in charge to keep any wild, dangerous, exotic, or poisonous animal on his premises in such a manner as to endanger the life or health of any person or other animal. Any wild, exotic, dangerous, or poisonous animal shall be securely and humanely confined or bound in such a manner as to prevent such animal from biting or attacking or frightening a person or other animal. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for any owner or person in charge to allow or permit any animal that is vicious or presumed to be vicious to be off the premises of the owner or person in charge, unless said animal is caged or leashed and muzzled and under effective restraint so as to prevent it from attacking or injuring a person or another animal. 
c.  It shall be unlawful for any owner or person in charge to keep or to permit to be kept on any residential premises any wild, exotic, vicious, or poisonous animal for display or for exhibition purposes for a fee. 
(9)  Capturing or killing birds. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to pursue, injure, capture, kill, or destroy any songbird of any kind, at any time, within the city. This section shall not be construed so as to apply to any animal control officer, any law enforcement officer, or other duly designated agent or employee of the city when a nuisance exists or when there is a hazard to health or safety which in the judgment of said officer cannot be otherwise remedied. 
b.  The city shall be, and the same is hereby designated as, a bird sanctuary. 
(10)  Horses at large. It shall be unlawful for any owner or person in charge to allow a horse to stand in any street within the city unless the owner or person in charge is in attendance or the horse is securely hitched. Any horse not so attended or securely hitched shall be considered to be at large. The owner or person in charge of any horse will be required to attach to said horse a diaper, bag, or other device designed to collect feces in such a manner as to collect the feces of said horse while the horse is on a public street, thoroughfare, or trail, or is otherwise in a public place, including, but not limited to, parks, trails, and other public areas. 
(11)  Chaining of animals. Animals shall not be tied or chained in a manner that presents a hazard to themselves or to the general public. 
(12)  Owner's duty to remove overturned or scattered garbage. It shall be the duty of the owner or person in charge of any dog or cat that has been allowed by said person to run at large to pick up and remove to the landfill, or to a secure authorized container, any garbage or refuse which said animal has caused to be overturned, spilled, or scattered upon any residential lot occupied for human habitation, or upon any right-of-way adjacent thereto. It shall be unlawful for any such person to fail or refuse to pick up said refuse upon demand from the owner or occupant thereof, or upon demand of any animal control officer, any law enforcement officer, or any other duly designated agent or employee of the city; provided, however, that no prosecution shall be commenced and no arrest made pursuant to this section except upon affidavit made before and summons and complaint or warrant issued by a duly appointed municipal judge or magistrate of the city. 
(13)  Duty of owner for removal of feces. 
a.  It shall be the duty of the owner or person in charge of any dog, cat, or horse to remove and dispose of any feces deposited by said animal upon the grounds of any public park or public place, upon any residential lot or another occupied for human habitation, upon any lot utilized for commercial or industrial purposes, or upon any right-of-way adjacent thereto. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to remove such feces upon demand by the owner or occupant thereof or by any animal control officer, law enforcement officer, or other duly designated agent or employee of the city; provided, however, that no prosecution shall be commenced and no arrest made pursuant to this section except upon affidavit made before and summons and complaint or warrant issued by a municipal judge or magistrate. 
(14)  Duty to restrain dogs and cats. 
a.  It shall be the duty of every owner or person in charge of a dog to keep said animal under effective restraint while the same is within the city, and it shall be unlawful for the owner or person in charge of any dog to fail to keep said animal under effective restraint. Proof that a dog is not properly restrained off the premises of the owner or person in charge shall be prima-facie evidence of a violation. Negligent failure to provide or maintain effective restraint shall not be a defense. Competent evidence that said failure was occasioned by an unforeseeable and independent act of a third person shall shift the burden on the city to prove otherwise. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for the owner or any person having custody or control of any cat within the city to allow such cat to be a nuisance or cause destruction or damage to the property of another. 
c.  No prosecution shall be commenced and no arrest made pursuant to this section except upon affidavit made before and summons and complaint or warrant issued by a judge or magistrate of municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 98-013 ADM, § 2, 4-14-98; Ord. No. 2008-030-ADM, § 1, 12-23-08; Ord. No. 2017-027-ADM, § 1, 5-23-17) 
Sec. 10-53. - Impoundment. 
(1)  Apprehension of animals running at large. Any animal found running at large or without the rabies tag and collar required in this article may be picked up by the city, impounded, and confined in a humane manner. Any animal found running at large or without the rabies tag and collar required by this ordinance and which is found on the property of a person, firm, or corporation other than that of its owner may be detained by the owner or occupant thereof for the purpose of permitting said animal to be picked up by the city, as is otherwise provided by this article; provided, however, that such detention shall be authorized only if said property owner or occupant promptly notifies the city of said detention and requests that the animal be picked up; further provided that nothing herein shall authorize the indefinite detention or conversion of any animal, the injury or destruction of any animal, or the disposition of any animal except in accordance with the procedures established and authorized by this article. 
(2)  Apprehension of cats or felines. Any cat found on the property of a person, firm, or corporation other than that of its owner may be detained by the owner or occupant thereof for the purpose of permitting said animal to be picked up by the city, as is otherwise provided by this article; provided however, that such detention shall be authorized only if said property owner or occupant promptly notifies the city of said detention and requests that the animal be picked up; further provided that nothing herein shall authorize the indefinite detention or conversion of any animal, the injury or destruction of any animal, or the disposition of any animal except in accordance with the procedures established and authorized by this article. 
(3)  Notice of impoundment. Upon the impounding of any animal, the city shall make reasonable effort to notify the owner of the animal so impounded, in writing or otherwise, and to inform the owner of the conditions under which he may regain custody of such animal. 
(4)  Electronic identification. The city may, at its option, require implantation of a microchip on any animal not identified by a collar and/or a tag and which is impounded or otherwise detained under this article. The owner shall be responsible for all costs associated with this procedure. 
(5)  Redemption. Any owner shall be entitled to resume possession of any impounded animal, except as provided in the cases of fierce, dangerous, or vicious animals, upon compliance with the inoculation requirements of this ordinance and the payment of impoundment, board fees, inoculation fees, and other fees under this article. 
(6)  Reclamation fees. 
a.  Any impounded animal may be reclaimed by the owner, as provided in this division, upon payment by the owner to the city or the agency contracted by the city, of the following fees: 
i.  Daily board; 
ii.  The inoculation fee, if required, plus any penalty due; 
iii.  The impoundment fee; 
iv.  Other fees, such as the electronic identification fee or fees imposed by the kennel which housed the animal. 
v.  A fee equal to the boarding fee charged to the city by the boarding agency. 
b.  For a second such impoundment of the same animal within a 12-calendar-month period, the animal impoundment fee shall be doubled. For a third or subsequent animal impoundment within that period, the impoundment fee to the owner shall be tripled, provided that such fees shall not exceed statutory maximums. 
(7)  Owner responsibility. The owner of any impounded animal shall be legally responsible for the fees and charges of such impoundment whether or not the animal is claimed. The city shall have the right to assess and collect any and all fees and charges from said owner. 
(8)  Unredeemed animals. 
a.  If any impounded animal is not reclaimed by its owner within seven days from delivery, the city may humanely destroy it or may transfer title to it and give ownership of it as provided in this section. 
b.  After the legal detention period of seven days has expired and an impounded animal has not been claimed by its owner, then the city may transfer the legal title to and give absolute ownership of any impounded animal to any of the following: 
i.  The Animal Rescue Center, the Metro Animal Shelter, the Humane Society, Alabama Animal Adoption Society, or licensed animal clinic, without fee, provided such society agrees to inoculate such animal to the satisfaction of the city; or 
ii.  Any person deemed by the city to be a responsible and suitable owner who shall agree to comply with the provisions of this section, including inoculation and payment of the required fees. 
(9)  Stray animals. Any person within the city finding any animal running at large about the residence of which he or she has charge may take custody of said animal and deliver the animal to any city officer empowered to enforce the provisions of this article, as an at-large or stray animal, regardless of whether the owner is known or not known or whether the animal bears a license or identification tag. 
(10)  Authority to destroy strays. The city or its duly designated agent shall have the authority to destroy any stray domestic animal running at large within the city limits when such animal constitutes a public nuisance or a danger or menace to the life or health of the citizenry of the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-013 ADM, § 3, 4-14-98; Ord. No. 98-019 ADM, 5-12-98) 
Sec. 10-54. - Violation and penalties. 
(1)  Complaint procedure. Any citizen wishing to make a complaint of a violation of this article may present himself or herself to the city magistrate to commence proceedings against the person in violation of the article. The complaining individual must swear under oath that the violation occurred and, if the magistrate has probable cause to believe that the offense as described constitutes a violation of this article, a summons and complaint may be issued to the individual. No summons and complaint shall be issued for violations of subsection 10-52(1)d. or 10-52(7) of this article unless affidavits by three different persons residing in or occupying different premises in the area where the violation occurred have been sworn to and subscribed before the magistrate, and the magistrate has probable cause to believe the offense as set out in the affidavits constitutes a violation of this article. 
(2)  Issuance of summons and complaint by law enforcement officer. Any law enforcement officer of the city or any law enforcement officer of the state shall be authorized to issue a summons and complaint to any person charged with a violation of this chapter. Such summons and complaint procedure shall be in lieu of custodial arrest. 
(3)  Summons and complaint procedure by law enforcement officer. When a person is arrested for a violation of this article, the officer shall take the name and address of said person and any other information required by law and shall then issue the summons and complaint to the individual. Such individual shall not be taken into custody upon his written promise to appear in court at the designated time and place as evidenced by his signature. The signing of the summons and complaint shall serve as adequate bond for that individual. If the individual refuses to provide his or her personal written recognizance to appear by signing the summons and complaint, the authorized officer shall place him into custody and bring him before any officer or official authorized to approve bond. 
(4)  Settlement of charges. When a person is charged with a violation of this article, and when that person desires to waive legal process on the question of his innocence and plead guilty and voluntarily settle the charge, he or she may do so by pleading guilty and paying a sum to the municipal court magistrate. A plea of guilty shall be accepted by the magistrate only after the defendant has executed the notice and waiver of rights provision on the summons and complaint. Settlement fines will be assessed pursuant to the following schedule, which may be amended from time to time by the city council: 
a.  First violation within 12 months: $50.00 fine plus court costs; 
b.  Second violation within 12 months: mandatory court appearance with the fine of no more than $500.00 plus costs and expenses to be assessed by the court. 
For the purposes of the above schedule, the 12-month period will commence upon conviction or settlement of each violation. 
(5)  Payment of fine. The above fines and costs may be voluntarily paid to the municipal court magistrate not later than 72 hours before the court date shown on the summons and complaint. The magistrate shall be authorized to receive the amount in full settlement of the alleged offense and to give a receipt on the behalf of the city. If such payment is made, no further prosecution for that specific violation shall be instituted or maintained in any court. All such payments must be made by personally appearing before said magistrate. 
(6)  Trial. Any offender wishing to plead not guilty to a violation or who is otherwise required to appear in court for a violation of this article must execute a signature and written personal recognizance bond with the court magistrate assuring his or her appearance to answer the charge in municipal court of the city upon a date certain. 
(7)  Rights of the defendant. All owners of animals subject to the provisions of this article shall have the right to enter a plea of not guilty to any violation charged against said defendant and secure a trial in the municipal court. 
(8)  Failure to appear or properly settle charges. If the defendant fails to voluntarily settle his or her charges or fails to appear as specified in the summons and complaint, the municipal court judge may issue a warrant for his or her arrest commanding that he or she be brought before the court to answer the charge contained in the summons and complaint. In addition, any person who willfully violates his or her written promise or bond to appear shall be guilty of the separate offense of failure to appear, which is a misdemeanor, regardless of the disposition of the charge upon which he or she was originally arrested. 
(9)  Review of prior charges. The municipal court, upon conviction, shall have the duty and responsibility to consider all prior charges brought against the offender (whether settled or not) and will specifically consider all charges in the last twelve months. 
(10)  Additional power of the municipal court. The municipal judge shall have the following additional legal authority in connection with this ordinance and the enforcement thereof. Said authority shall include the following: 
a.  Upon a sworn complaint being made by a citizen, a duly authorized municipal officer or employee, or a law enforcement officer of the city to the court clerk, the court shall be authorized to issue the following orders: 
i.  To direct seizure, impoundment, and/or the delivery of said animal to the city's impoundment center; 
ii.  To order that the animal be destroyed if there exists a reasonable necessity for said action; 
iii.  To assess all costs or expenses to the victim, including restitution, against said owner or responsible person; 
iv.  To increase the amount of the fine above that specified in the schedule. 
b.  Upon the trial and conviction of an owner for a violation of any provision of this article, the municipal court shall have the authority to issue the following orders, in addition to all other power and authority conferred by law: 
i.  To impose on the defendant a requirement that the animal be destroyed or removed from the city limits; 
ii.  To impose as a specific condition on the defendant reasonable conditions and restrictions relating to the possession and/or control of the animal; 
iii.  Such other terms and conditions as the court may deem proper under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 98-013 ADM, § 4, 4-14-98; Ord. No. 2008-030-ADM, § 1, 12-23-08) 
Sec. 10-55. - Inoculation. 
(1)  Inoculation. No person shall own, possess, keep, or harbor in the city any animal that has not been inoculated against rabies within the preceding 12 months and tagged as required by Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 3-7-2 and 3-7-4. The required tag shall be displayed by attaching same to the animal's collar. 
a.  Release from impoundment. No impounded animal shall be released from impoundment unless or until the same is inoculated or a proper certificate and tag is presented which shows that the animal has been inoculated in accordance with state law and this article. 
b.  Inoculation by city. An owner or other person entitled to possession of any impounded animal who does not have the required inoculation certificate and tag for the animal may elect to have the animal inoculated at the impoundment center upon payment of a fee as set from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 98-013 ADM, § 5, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 10-56. - Registration. 
(1)  Registration required for wild or exotic animals. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, to keep, maintain, possess or have under their control any wild or exotic animal without registering said animal with the city. 
b.  The owner or person in charge of any wild or exotic animal shall annually register the same for breed, description, and name and address of the owner or person in charge with the city. The registration shall be effective for one year from date of issue, and must be renewed each year on or before the anniversary date of issue. 
c.  The provisions of this section shall not apply to lawfully operated and located pet shops, zoological gardens, scientific research laboratories, circuses, veterinarians harboring such animals for purposes of providing professional medical treatment, or wildlife rehabilitators with proper permits, provided that the animals are maintained in quarters so constructed and maintained as to prevent escape. 
d.  The confinement of wild or exotic animals must meet the regulations promulgated by the State of Alabama Wildlife Commission, the minimum standards under the Animal Welfare Act, and all applicable rules promulgated by the United States Department of Agriculture. In addition to meeting the above minimum standards, all venomous reptiles and all wild or exotic animals shall be confined, restrained, and controlled in fully enclosed quarters and in such manner that the physical safety or property of any person lawfully entering the premises shall not be endangered and so as to prevent escape of such animal. 
e.  Privately owned wild or exotic animals shall not be allowed on any public street, sidewalk, or other public way except in a fully enclosed cage or with adequate structural restraint. The use of a leash, with or without a muzzle, shall not be considered adequate restraint. 
(Ord. No. 98-013 ADM, § 6, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 10-57. - Authority and enforcement. 
(1)  Enforcement. The provisions of this article are enforceable by any city animal control officer, law enforcement officer, or other duly designated agent or employee of the city. Said officer has the right to go onto private property when necessary to apprehend an animal in violation of this article. 
(2)  Interference with officer. No person or owner shall interfere with, hinder, molest, prevent, or obstruct in any way or form an officer, employee, or agent of the city in the enforcement of this ordinance or in the performance of their duties or release any animal in the custody of the said officer, agent, or employee. 
(3)  Violation/penalties. Any person violating any provision of this ordinance shall, upon conviction, be fined an amount not to exceed $500.00 and also may be imprisoned in jail for a term not to exceed 180 days. 
(4)  Charges for confinement and caring for dogs and cats. 
a.  The city shall charge and collect fees from owners who redeem their animals. The city shall have the authority to establish a fee schedule entitled "Fee Schedule for Animal Control Center" for the following categories: 
i.  Impoundment: dog or cat; 
ii.  Boarding: dog and cat per day; 
iii.  Adoption: dog or cat; 
iv.  Special fees: pickup, disposal, microchip implantation, vaccination required by kennel. 
b.  The fee schedule will not include applicable charges for any license or rabies vaccination that is required by this article or other applicable law. 
c.  Animals may not be adopted by original owners or their immediate family members so as to avoid paying a violation fine or redemption fee. 
(Ord. No. 98-013 ADM, § 7, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 10-58. - Miscellaneous. 
(1)  Companion animals. No owner, lessee, proprietor, manager, superintendent, agent or employee of any place of public accommodation, amusement, or recreation shall refuse to permit a companion animal to accompany a disabled person entering such place or making use of the accommodations available when the companion animal is wearing a harness or is otherwise restrained. Establishments covered under this provision include, but are not limited to any hotel, restaurant, eating establishment, barbershop, billiard parlor, store, mall, public conveyance, theater, public educational institution, or elevator. 
(Ord. No. 98-013 ADM, § 8, 4-14-98)

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS AND ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 14-1. - Designation of code official/duties of official and inspectors. 
    The building official of the city, or his/her designated representative(s) in the city's engineering and inspections department, shall serve as the code official for purposes of this chapter and be responsible for enforcement of the building and technical codes. The code official, along with his/her authorized representatives, shall inspect or cause to be inspected all installations, alterations, or repairs to buildings or properties in the city required by this chapter, and shall have the right to enter any building, structure or premises within the city to perform any duties imposed upon him or her by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-2. - Applicability to all contractors. 
    The provisions of this chapter are applicable to any person, corporation, organization, or other entity engaged in the construction industry or performing construction, alteration, renovation or repair operations with respect to a new or existing building, structure or premises in the city, including, but not limited to, homebuilders, remodelers, commercial contractors and associated subcontractors who perform electrical, plumbing, gas, mechanical, or other building trade work (collectively for purposes of this chapter, "contractors"). 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-3. - Inspections. 
(a)  Work required by this chapter or the building and technical codes to be permitted shall be inspected by the city's engineering and inspections department unless such inspection requirement is waived by the code official. 
(b)  Any contractor or permit holder who requests the city's engineering and inspections department to perform an inspection contemplated by this chapter or to provide non-emergency service shall notify that department at least 24 hours in advance of the requested service. No contractor may conceal any part of the work for which an inspection is required until after approval by the code official. Also, the contractor, permit holder or other person requesting an inspection or other service from the engineering and inspections department is required to be on site when any such inspection or service is performed. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-4. - Business license requirement/no use of license by third party. 
(a)  All contractors, businesses or persons performing work for profit shall obtain a proper, valid business license(s) before performing their respective operations at a work site, shall maintain such license(s) (or a copy(ies) thereof) at each such site, and shall produce a copy of same there upon request of the code official or any other representative of the engineering and inspections department. 
(b)  After obtaining a proper business license, no contractor shall allow its, his or her business name to be used by another contractor or person, directly or indirectly, to obtain a construction permit under the name of the licensed business. Further, each contractor or person obtaining a business license for construction work shall submit accurate license returns to the city and not make misrepresentations or omissions therein. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-5. - Foundation survey requirement. 
    In addition to any other requirements elsewhere in this chapter or in the city's zoning ordinance, no contractor may commence the framing of a building or structure until either the contractor, builder or owner of the premises has furnished the building official a foundation survey signed by a land surveyor licensed in the State of Alabama. For any structure within the RG zoning district, such survey also must indicate the location of any buildings abutting the property on which the subject structure is to be built or labelled a vacant lot. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-6. - References to officials. 
    When a reference is made herein or in the adopted building or technical codes to certain named officials, the official of the City of Trussville whose duties most closely correspond to those of such named official shall be deemed the official responsible for the enforcement of said codes and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Secs. 14-7-14-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS 

Sec. 14-11. - Application and general requirement. 
    No contractor (or other person required to secure a permit) may perform any of the following types of projects, operations or work, or cause any such work to be done, without first applying to the city's engineering and inspections department and obtaining the required permit(s) for that work: 
(1)  Any work involving the construction, addition, repair, demolition, or excavation of a building, structure or premises within the city; 
(2)  Any project to enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish or change the occupancy of a building, tenant space, or structure; or 
(3)  Any work to erect, install, enlarge, alter, repair, remove, convert, or replace any electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing system that is regulated by the building and technical codes adopted in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-12. - Submission of plans/fee payment obligation. 
    Contractors and other applicants for permits shall submit information concerning the nature of that work to the code official before commencing those operations. Upon the code official certifying that said plans conform to applicable city building and technical codes and ordinances, the engineering and inspections department shall issue a permit(s) for that work, subject to payment of fees as hereinafter provided to the appropriate city office. 
    Whenever, in the opinion of the code official, an application for a permit does not include sufficient clarity or detail to definitely show the nature and character of the work, the code official may require the applicant to supply plans and specifications for that work that are drawn to scale and furnished in duplicate sets to the engineering and inspections department. The information on such plans and specifications shall be specific, and neither general references thereon in part or in whole to the building and technical codes nor the term "legal" (or its equivalents) may be used as a substitute for specific information. After those plans are reviewed by the engineering and inspections department, one set of them shall be returned to the applicant and marked "reviewed copy," and one set shall be retained and filed as a permanent record in the office of the code official. Further, the applicant must retain a set of the reviewed/job copy plans on the work or job site at all times. 
    Unless otherwise waived by the code official, the plans for building permits shall reflect and include the following detail and information: 
(1)  A plot plan depicting the actual shape, proportion and dimensions of the lot. This plot plan shall show all easements and floodplain information; 
(2)  The shape, size, use, and location of all buildings, signs, or other structures to be erected, altered or moved on the lot, and of any buildings or other structures already on the lot, both above and below existing grade; 
(3)  The setback lines on the lot along with any easements of record, and such other information concerning the lot or adjoining lots as may be essential for determining conformance with the provisions of this chapter; 
(4)  Written certification from the appropriate Jefferson or St. Clair County department that adequate sewerage treatment facilities are available at the proposed site. In areas where sanitary sewer is available, proof of payment of the sewer impact fee to Jefferson County Environmental Service Department or counterpart authority for St. Clair County shall be required; 
(5)  Where applicable, two full sets of detailed construction drawings on sheets not less than 11 inches by 17 inches nor larger than 36 inches by 48 inches; 
(6)  An electronic copy of the plans; and 
(7)  A list naming all sub-contractors who will perform work under the permit. If the list of all subcontractors is not available at the time of application, the applicant must submit that list within 15 days of permit issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-13. - Expiration/continuous performance requirement. 
    A permit shall expire in accordance with adopted building and technical codes. Any permit issued under this chapter shall remain valid and in effect only if the work contemplated by the permit is continuously performed. A permit shall be deemed to have expired for failure to satisfy this continuous work requirement and no longer be effective if any of the following circumstance occur: 
(1)  For construction work on a project or system not involving work on the exterior of a building or structure, the permit shall expire if no work has been performed within six months from the date of its issuance; provided that, following the effective expiration of the permit, application for a one-time renewal of the permit must be made to and approved by the code official prior to recommencing work. If the permit is renewed, however, the provisions of all ordinances in force at the time of the renewal shall apply; 
(2)  For construction work on a project not involving work on the exterior of a building or structure, the permit shall expire if the permitted operations are commenced but that work was suspended, ceased to be performed or abandoned for a period of six months after commencement; provided that, following the effective expiration of the permit, application for a one-time renewal of the permit may be made to and approved by the code official prior to recommencing work. If the permit is renewed, however, the provisions of all ordinances in force at the time of the renewal shall apply; or 
(3)  For construction work involving work on the exterior of a building or structure, the permit shall expire if work on the project ceases for a period of 30 days and work on the exterior remains incomplete; provided that, if the permit contemplated in this expires due to the circumstances in this subpart, the permit shall be required to be renewed prior to recommencing work and reissued at one-half the initial expense upon the recommendation of the code official. 
    In addition to the penalties set forth in this chapter for failing to continuously perform and complete permitted work, the code official also may determine that the property on which exterior or systems of a building are not timely completed be declared a public nuisance pursuant to applicable Alabama law or city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-14. - Deficient work suspension of right to use permit. 
    Any contractor whose work does not conform to the building and technical codes of the city or other provisions in this chapter, whose workmanship or materials are of inferior quality or whose work is not in scope of permit shall, on notice from the code official, promptly make necessary changes or corrections at once so as to conform thereto. If deficient work on a project has not been so corrected after ten days' notice, the code official may then suspend the contractor's right to conduct operations under any permit previously issued on a project and refuse to issue any more permits on that project or job site until actions are taken bring the deficient work in compliance with the city's codes and ordinances. Further, in the event that a contractor demonstrates a pattern of noncompliance with the building and technical codes, permit requirements or provisions in this or other ordinance, the code official may decline to issue new permits for a contractor on other projects in the city until its deficient work is corrected. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-15. - Stop work orders for dangerous and unsafe conditions. 
    The code official may direct that construction work or operations on a building or structure cease under any of the following conditions: (a) the contractor's work has been performed or is not being performed in compliance with the building and technical codes, this chapter or other city ordinances; (b) that work or those operations have created or may create conditions that are deemed by the code official to be dangerous or unsafe to persons or property; (c) the contractor is working without a required permit; or (d) the work or operations violate the city's zoning ordinance. Notice of any stop work order shall be delivered to either (i) the person shown on the records of the Jefferson County Tax Assessor or St. Clair County Tax Assessor as being last assessed for ad valorem taxes on the subject property or (ii) the contractor or other person known to the code official to have performed the work creating those conditions. The notice shall describe the dangerous conditions, the nature of the violation and the undertakings required before work on the building or system may resume. Except for persons engaged to take remedial action to correct any dangerous and unsafe conditions, any contractor or other person who continues construction work or operations in or about the subject structure or system after having received a stop work order shall be subject to penalties as prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-16. - Qualifications for electrician to obtain permit. 
    For work performed within the city to install electrical wiring or electrical systems that is not exempt from permitting and inspection requirements, no permit will be issued to an electrician who desires to perform such work unless the electrician presents evidence to the code official as holding at least one of the following valid and effective licenses at the time of permit application: 
(1)  Master electrical license from the State of Alabama. 
(2)  Master electrical license from the City of Birmingham, Alabama. 
(3)  Master electrical license from Jefferson County, Alabama. 
(4)  Master electrical license from Shelby County, Alabama. 
(5)  Master electrical license from St. Clair County, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-17. - Qualifications for plumber to obtain permit. 
    For plumbing system work performed within the city that is not exempt from permitting and inspection requirements, no permit will be issued to a plumber who desires to perform such work unless the plumber presents evidence to the code official as holding a master plumbing license issued by the State of Alabama that is valid and effective at the time of permit application. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Sec. 14-18. - Additional requirements of permit. 
(a)  Exterior work authorized under any permit provided for in this chapter shall be performed only between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. Monday thru Saturday. No such work shall be performed on Sundays, on holidays or outside these hours unless a written exception is approved by the mayor. Applications for exceptions must be made to the code official. 
(b)  Within 15 days after issuance of a building permit to a primary contractor on a project, that contractor shall be responsible to furnish the engineering and inspections department a list identifying each subcontractors retained by the primary contractor on the project and evidencing that each of those subcontractors is properly licensed to conduct business in the City of Trussville. No inspections will be scheduled on the project until the primary contractor furnishes this list of subcontractors and evidence of their associated licenses. Further, the engineering and inspections department will not release any electric meter or gas meter until all subcontractors and suppliers on a permitted project are properly licensed. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16) 
Secs. 14-19-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PERMIT AND CONSTRUCTION FEES 

Sec. 14-31. - General requirements/obligation to pay fees. 
    The fees set forth below are payable with respect to permits, construction-related work and other operations performed or to be performed in the city. No permit shall be issued and no inspection contemplated under this chapter shall be scheduled until these fees shall have been paid; further, no requested amendment to a permit will be approved until the additional permit fees related to that request, if any, shall have been paid. 
    When determining the value of work for purposes of calculating the permit fees in this section, that valuation shall be determined by reference to bona tide signed contracts or other evidence of cost of the work as submitted by the owner or contractor, but in no event shall the value of the work be less than the most recent publication of the International Code Council Building Valuation Data Chart. The valuation shall include the total amount to complete the project, including, but not limited to, painting, hardwood, tile, carpet, and non-structural items. 
(1)  Fees for building and construction, electrical, fire suppression system, plumbing and gas, mechanical, litigation, structural sign building and low voltage permits. 
a.  Permit fees. The permit fee shall be $7.00 for each $1,000.00, or fraction thereof, of the contract (plus land) cost or estimated valuation, whichever is greater, plus $23.00 issuance fee. The permit fees shall increase according to the chart below until July 1, 2017.

Such state required fees and charges may be adjusted from time to time as required by state law or regulation. 
b.  Minimum permit fee. The minimum permit fee shall be valuation or contract cost per $1,000.00 plus issuance fee.

a.  Notice of any request to cancel a scheduled morning inspection must be delivered (verbally or in writing) and actually received by a representative of the engineering and inspections department prior to 8:00 a.m. local time of the day of the scheduled inspection; and 
b.  Notice of any request to cancel an afternoon inspection must be delivered (verbally or in writing) and actually received by a representative of the engineering and inspections department prior to 12:00 p.m. of the day of the scheduled inspection.

Sec. 14-32. - Fees when working without permit. 
    Where work for which a permit is required starts or proceeds prior to obtaining said permit, the contractor or other person responsible to obtain such permit shall pay double the permit fees specified in the applicable codes or ordinances to obtain the required permit. The payment of such double fees or other charges specified herein shall not relieve that contractor or person from performing the work in full compliance with the requirements in the applicable codes or ordinances. Moreover, any person who fails to obtain a required permit before commencing work shall be subject to additional penalties for violations as provided herein. 
    If a contractor or other person who works in the city without a required permit incurs a double permit fee on a project and thereafter performs other work in the city without obtaining a required permit, the following fees and charges will apply: 
First time ..... Double permit 
Second time ..... $100.00 plus double permit 
Third time ..... $250.00 plus double permit 
Fourth time ..... $500.00 plus double permit 
Fifth time ..... $500.00 plus double permit plus revocation of business license 
    If a contractor does not commit a working-without-permit offense within the one-year period that follows its last such offense, the next violation shall be considered a first time offense for purposes of applying this provision. 
(Ord. No. 2016-001-ADM, 1-12-16)

ARTICLE IV. - ADOPTION OF BUILDING AND TECHNICAL CODES 

Sec. 14-41. - International Building Code adopted by reference. 
(a)  Except as provided below in subsection (b), the International Building Code, 2015 edition ("IBC"), including appendix chapters E, F, G, I, J, and K, as published by the International Code Council ("ICC"), is hereby adopted as the Building Code of the City of Trussville by reference as though copied herein. A copy of the IBC is on file in the engineering and inspections department of the city, and same is available for purchase at the ICC offices currently located at 900 Montclair Road, Birmingham, Alabama. 
    Among other matters, the IBC includes regulations that promote the safe, sanitary, and fit occupation and use of structures and facilitates the permitting and inspection process for construction of buildings. 
(b)  The following additions, insertions, deletions, and modifications to the below referenced sections of the IBC are adopted by the city and shall supersede any conflicting provisions in the IBC: 
101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Building Code of the City of Trussville, which hereinafter may be referenced in this Section as "this code." 
101.4.8 Electrical. The provisions of the National Electrical Code shall apply to the installation of electrical systems, including alterations, repairs, replacement, equipment appliances, fixtures, fittings, and appurtenances thereof. 
105.2 Work Exempt from Permit. Permits shall not be required under this code for the following work: 
Building: 
Sidewalks, not more than 30 inches (762 mm) above adjacent grade, and not over any basement or story below and are not part of any accessible route; 
Painting; 
Temporary motion picture, television, and theater stage sets and scenery; 
Prefabricated swimming pools accessory to a Group R-3 occupancy that are less than 24 inches (610 nun) deep, do not exceed 5,000 gallons (18,925 L) and are installed entirely above ground; 
Shade cloth structures constructed for nursery or agriculture purposes, not including service systems; 
Swings and other playground equipment accessory to detached one- and two-family dwellings; and 
Non-fixed and movable fixtures, cases, racks, counters, and partitions not over 5 feet 9 inches (1753 mm) in height; 
Notwithstanding, these exemptions from the permit requirement of this code shall not deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of this code or any other laws or ordinances of the City. 
107.1. General. Permit applicants shall submit information consisting of construction documents, plans, a statement of special inspections, a geotechnical report, and other data pertinent to the project in two or more sets, along with an electronic copy thereof. The construction documents and plans shall be prepared by a licensed design professional specified in section 107.1.1. Where special conditions exist, the Code Official is authorized to require additional construction documents to be prepared by a registered design professional. 
Exception: The Code Official may waive the requirements for submission of construction documents or preparation of such documents by a licensed design professional if that Official determines that the review of construction documents or preparation of same by such a professional is not necessary to comply with this code. 
107.1.1. Construction Documents and Plans Shall Be Prepared by a Design Professional. The construction documents and plans contemplated in this Ordinance shall be prepared by a design professional; for purposes of this Ordinance, that person shall be an architect or engineer licensed under the laws of the State of Alabama. That design professional shall affix his/her official seal to plans, documents and drawings submitted with applications for permit. Engineered plans shall be submitted for electrical, mechanical and plumbing work, including specifications and accompanying data. Plans on all group occupancy projects, excluding R-3 (single family homes), shall be designed by an architect. 
114.4 Violations Penalties. See Sec 14-77 and other provisions in this Ordinance. 
903.2.8 This provision of the IBC is not adopted. 
1013.1.1 Exit Signs. Exit signs shall not be located more than 4 feet above exit door. 
1210.2.1 Surrounding Material. Tile or sealed masonry shall be required in Group A, E, M, and B occupancy projects. Approved alternate material may be used in business occupancy projects less than 1500 square feet in area.

Sec. 14-43. - International Existing Building Code adopted by reference. 
(a)  Except as provided below in subsection (b), the International Existing Building Code, 2015 edition ("IEBC"), as published by the International Code Council ("ICC"), is hereby adopted as the existing building code of the City of Trussville by reference as though copied herein. A copy of the IEBC is on file in the engineering and inspections department of the city, and same is available for purchase at the ICC offices currently located at 900 Montclair Road, Birmingham, Alabama. 
(b)  The following additions, insertions, deletions, and modifications to the below referenced sections of the IEBC are adopted by the city and shall supersede any conflicting provisions in the IEBC: 
101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Existing Building Code of the City of Trussville, which hereinafter may be referenced in this Section as "this code." 
105.1.3 Moving Permit. A building or part of any building shall not be moved through or across any sidewalk, street, alley or highway within the City's corporate limits without first obtaining a permit from the Engineering and Inspections Department. Any person desiring to move a building shall first file with the Code Official a written application for permit setting forth the following information: 
1.  Type and kind of building to be moved; 
2.  The original cost of such building; 
3.  The extreme dimensions of the length, height and width of the building; 
4.  The present location and proposed new location of the building by lot, block, subdivision and street numbers; and 
5.  The approximate time the building to be moved will be on or along the streets, and the route that will be taken from present to new location. 
105.1.3.1 Permit Refusal. A request for a permit to move a building may be denied if, in the reasonable opinion of the Code Official or Police Chief, the requested move creates a substantial risk of injury to any person, likely will cause damage to private property, will result in damage to streets or other public improvements, the subject building has deteriorated more than 50 percent of its current value by fire or other element, or moving the building will violate any of the requirements of the City's codes or zoning regulations. 
105.1.3.2. Route of Move. Before issuing any building moving permit, the Code Official shall provide notice to the City's Engineering Department, Fire Chief and Police Chief of the Code Official's intent to grant such permit. The Engineering Department and Police Department shall specify the moving route to be used, start time, and approximate time for completion of the move for the permit before it is delivered to the applicant. 
105.1.3.3. Public Safety Requirements. If any part of a contemplated building move will or may occur after sundown and those operations will involve the use of public streets or other public property, the moving permit holder or owner of the building shall provide the following safeguards between sunset and sunrise to protect the public: 
(a)  A minimum of five red lights shall be placed on each street side of the building. Such red lights shall be continuously illuminated and attached to the building in such a fashion as to indicate extreme width, height, and size; 
(b)  In addition to the red lights on the building, flares shall be placed at regular intervals for a distance of 200 ft (61 m) up to the street on each side of the building; and 
(c)  When more than 50 percent of the street, measured between curbs, is occupied at night by the building, or when, in the opinion of the Code Official, flagmen are necessary to divert or caution traffic, the owner or person moving such building shall employ at his/hers expense, two flagmen, one at each street intersection beyond the building. Such flagmen shall in accordance with City Ordinance and remain at these intersections diverting or cautioning traffic from sunset to sunrise. Red lights shall be employed in flagging traffic at night. 
105.1.3.4. Improvements by Owner. The owner or mover of any of any building or structure proposed to be moved shall make all necessary improvements required for said structure to comply with the requirements of this code within 90 days from the date of the issuance of the moving permit. Extensions of time to make these improvements may be granted by the Code Official upon a showing of delay caused by circumstances beyond the reasonable control of the owner or mover. The application for the moving permit, accompanied by complete plans and specifications showing the changes or conditions of said building, or structure as the same is proposed to be when moving, and all contemplated improvements, signed by the owner or the owner's agent. 
105.1.3.5. Limitations. If a moving permit is issued, no building being moved may occupy or remain on the City's streets for more than 48 hours, nor shall the building or moving operation block any street, road or thoroughfare without the express written permission of the Code Official. 
105.1.3.6. Bond or Security Required. The Code Official, as a condition precedent to the issuance of such a building move permit, shall require that the person requesting the permit furnish a bond, certificate of deposit, cash, cashier's check or other form of security that is acceptable to the City in its discretion in a minimum amount of Twenty Five Thousand Dollars ($25,000.00) to secure the applicant's obligation to reimburse the City for any damage caused by the moving of such building to streets, curbs, sidewalks, shade trees, highways and other City property which may be affected by that move. In addition, the applicant shall, before that permit is issued, also furnish the Engineering and Inspections Department a certificate of insurance evidencing that the applicant has general liability insurance for its proposed work in the City with the following minimum limits: Bodily Injury - $1,000,000.00 minimum for each occurrence; and Property Damage - $1,000,000.00 for each occurrence. 
Regulations of State Codes Board. As authorized in Title 11, Chapter 23 of the 1975 Code of Alabama in effect now or as hereafter amended, the Alabama Energy and Residential Codes Board also adopts codes and regulations applicable to the construction, alteration, movement, enlargement, replacement, repair, equipment, location, removal and demolition of detached one and two-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings (townhouses) not more than three stories in height with separate means of egress. In the event that any provision in the Energy Conservation Code of the City of Trussville conflicts with that in the 2015 Alabama Energy and Residential Codes, as amended and adopted by the Alabama Residential and Energy Codes Board on the effective date of this Ordinance (the "State Codes"), the provision in those State Codes shall control, supersede and govern.

R105.2 Work Exempt From Permit. Exemption from permit requirements of this Code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of this Code or any other laws or ordinances of this jurisdiction. Permits shall not be required under this code for the following work: 
Building: 
- Sidewalks; 
- Painting, papering, flooring, and carpeting; 
- Prefabricated swimming pools that are less than 24 inches (610 mm) deep; and 
- Swings and other playground equipment 
Notwithstanding, these exemptions from the permit requirement of this code shall not authorize any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of this code or any other laws or ordinances of the city.

R302.6 Alternate provisions. At the election of the contractor, the contractor may comply either with the requirements stated in section R302.6 of the IRC or with the following alternate provisions: 
Garage fire protection and suppression system. 
(a)  Garage opening protection. 
(1)  Openings from a private garage directly into a room used for sleeping purposes shall not be permitted. All openings between the garage and residence shall be equipped with an UL listed 20-minute fire-rated door. 
(b)  Separation required. 
(1)  The garage shall be separated from the residence and its attic area by not less than one-half-inch (12.7 mm) gypsum board applied to the garage side. Garages beneath habitable rooms shall be separated from all habitable rooms above by not less than five-eighths-inch (15.9 mm) Type X gypsum board or equivalent. Where the separation is a floor-ceiling assembly, the structure supporting the separation shall also be protected by not less than one-half-inch (12.7 mm) gypsum board or equivalent. 
(c)  Garage fire suppression system. 
(1)  This section allows for an alternative to subsection (b) of this section. 
a.  This system must be designed and installed by a licensed fire sprinkler contractor. 
b.  Minimum three-fourths-inch domestic water line for sprinkler demand with a one-inch domestic preferred. 
c.  A wall with not less than one-half gypsum board shall be built between the garage area and any finished or unfinished basement area which is not protected by the garage fire suppression system. Any doors in this separation wall shall have a UL listed, 20-minute fire rating. 
d.  For full unfinished basements with garage doors present, but without a separation wall (as required in subsection (c)(1)c. of this section), installing an automatic sprinkler system throughout the entire basement is required. A UL listed, 20-minute fire rated door separating the basement from the living area is required. 
e.  Required alarm notification. 
1.  Flow switch and tamper valves must be tied to an electronic bell to alert resident of a water flow situation or that supervised valve is turned off. The alarm bell must be mounted in the living area of the house, and in an area where the bell will not be obstructed or allow to have storage hinder its function. 
2.  In the event a home security alarm is installed in the house, the flow and tamper switches may be tied into the alarm system to audibly alert residents, so long as the alarm is located in the living area. 
f.  Fire suppression system components. 
1.  Supply piping to fire suppression system must be a minimum of one inch schedule 40 black pipe with sprinkler head spaced no greater than 14 feet apart on branch lines and no more than seven foot any wall (maximum of 144 square feet). PEX and other piping material may be used if it is UL listed for fire sprinkler distribution, and a copy of the UL listed is supplied to the fire marshal's office during the design process. 
2.  Sprinkler heads must be "quick response" (155 degree), standard spray with one-half-inch threaded and minimum of three-eighths-inch orifice size. Upright heads are recommended with deflector no more than four inches below bottom of ceiling joists. Pendant heads may be used in areas where horizontal obstructions dictate and located with deflectors just under obstruction. 
3.  Floor area beneath "open" garage doors must be protected. 
Recommend use of residential side wall heads mounted no more than two inches below the bottom plane of the garage doors in the open position. 
4.  Fire protection system riser must be tied to the domestic water system "upstream" from the pressure-reducing valve. All valves controlling water to the fire suppression system must be supervised; this includes valves that turn off the water to the entire house. This does not include the valve pit at the street. 
g.  Inspection for Compliance. 
1.  Building contractor or Sprinkler Contractor shall notify the City of Trussville Engineering and Inspections Department when the "entire" system and all other fire codes and ordinances are complete, and are ready to be tested and inspected. The fire marshal, or his/hers designated representative, will check for proper system components, alarm location, and head placement. 
(d)  Drop-in fire-rated ceiling assembly. 
(1)  This section allows for an alternative to subsection (b) of this section. 
a.  A UL-approved drop-in ceiling assembly (grid, hangers, lights, etc.) rated for one-hour fire resistance may be used as an alternative to subsection (b). 
b.  An inspection for compliance shall be done by the City of Trussville Engineering and Inspections Department at the rough-in stage and after installation is complete. 
c.  A wall with not less than one-half-inch gypsum board shall be built between the garage area and any finished or unfinished basement area. Any doors in this separation wall shall have a UL listing for 20-minute fire rating. 
(e)  Detection Devices. 
(1)  A heat or smoke detector shall be placed in all garage areas that are not equipped with an automatic fire sprinkler system. The contractor should verify that the normal operating temperatures for the device chosen is appropriate for the seasonal temperatures of the location where installed. This section does not pertain to basements. 
R314.3 Smoke Alarms. Smoke alarms shall be installed in the following locations: 
1.  In each sleeping room. 
2.  Outside each separate sleeping area, in the immediate vicinity of the bedrooms. 
3.  On each additional story of the dwelling, including basements and habitable attics and not including crawl spaces and uninhabitable attics. In dwellings or dwelling units with split levels and without an intervening door between the adjacent levels, a smoke alarm installed on the upper level shall suffice for the adjacent lower level provided that the lower level is less than one full story below the upper level. 
4.  Smoke alarms shall be installed not less than 3 feet (914mm) horizontally from the door or opening of a bathroom that contains a bathtub or shower unless this would prevent placement of a smoke alarm required by Section R314.3. 
5.  In each garage and subdivided basement area, in garage heat detector can be substituted for smoke detector. 
R401.1 Application. The provisions of this chapter shall control the design and construction of the foundation and foundation spaces for all buildings to include extensive renovations and the addition of stories to an existing structure. Existing footings for additional stories shall comply with section R403.1.1.1. In addition to the provisions of this chapter, the design and construction of foundations in areas prone to flooding as established by Table R301.2.1 shall meet the provisions of Section R322. Wood foundations shall be designed and installed in accordance with AWC PWF. 
Exception: The provisions of this chapter may be used for wood foundations only in the following situations: 
1.  In buildings that have no more than two floors and a roof. 
2.  When interior basement and foundation walls are constructed at intervals not exceeding 50 feet (15 240mm). 
Wood foundations in Seismic Design Category D, D1, D2, shall be designed in accordance with accepted engineering practice. 
R401.4.3 Foundation. Footings and foundations for new constructions and additions installed on a lot or parcel that has an average grade slope exceeding 1/3 shall be designed by a State of Alabama licensed engineer. A geotechnical engineer also shall be required to evaluate the site and inspect the footings and foundations. 
R403.1.1.1 Minimum Size Required on All Footings. The minimum size for concrete footings and reinforcement shall be: 
Exterior Walls:       10" thick by 24" width with 2 #4 rods continuous 
Interior Piers:       12" thick by 24" square width with 4 #4 rods 
Interior Grade Beams:       8" thick by 18" width with 2 #4 rods continuous 
R404.1.3 (1) Minimum Rebar Requirements for Poured Wall under 10 ft . Minimum rebar requirements for poured foundation walls is #4 rods 12 inches by 12 inches on center. Walls that exceed 10 feet in height shall be designed by an Alabama State Registered Engineer. 
R1004.1 General. Factory-built fireplaces shall be listed and labeled and shall be installed in accordance with the conditions of the listing. Factory-built fireplaces shall be tested in accordance with UL 127. Factory-built fireplace mantel and trim woodwork clearances shall comply with Table R1001.1 (view section R1001.11 exp. 4). Factory built vented fireplaces installed in bedrooms must be protected with a glass door assembly, a carbon monoxide detector, and an automatic gas shutoff device. Factory-built unvented fireplaces shall not be installed in bedrooms. 
Rl004.2 Hearth Extensions. Hearth extensions of approved factory-built fireplaces shall be installed in accordance with the listing of the fireplace. The hearth extension shall be readily distinguishable from the surrounding floor area. Factory-built fireplace minimum hearth extension dimensions shall comply with Section R1001.10. 
P2603.5.1 Sewer Depth. Building sewers that connect to private sewage disposal systems shall be a minimum of 6 inches (152 mm) below finished grade at the point of septic tank connection. Building sewers shall be a minimum of 6 inches (152 mm) below grade. 
P2804.6.1 Requirements for Discharge Pipe. The discharge piping serving a pressure relief valve, temperature relief valve or combination valve shall: 
1.  Not be directly connected to the drainage system. 
2.  Discharge through an air gap located in the same room as the water heater. 
3.  Not be smaller than the diameter of the outlet of the valve served and shall discharge full size to the air gap. 
4.  Serve a single relief device and shall not connect to piping serving any other relief device or equipment. 
5.  Discharge to the floor, to the pan serving the water heater or storage tank, to a waste receptor or to the outdoors. 
6.  Discharge in a manner that does not cause personal injury or structural damage. 
7.  Discharge to a termination point that is readily observable by the building occupants. 
8.  Not be trapped. 
9.  Be installed to flow by gravity. 
10.  Not terminate more than 6 inches (152 mm) above the floor or waste receptor. 
11.  Not have a threaded connection at the end of the piping. 
12.  Not have valves or tee fittings. 
13.  Be constructed of those materials listed in Section P2906.5 or materials tested, rated, and approved for such use in accordance with ASME A112.4.4. 
14.  Not have more than four 90 degree bends and not to exceed 30 feet in length. 
15.  Be one nominal size larger than the size of the relief-valve outlet, where the relief- valve discharge piping is constructed of PEX or PE-RT tubing. The outlet end of such tubing shall be fastened in place. 
P2904 Dwelling Unit Fire Sprinkler Systems . This entire section is not adopted. 
P3103.1 Roof Extension. All open vent pipes which extend through a roof shall be terminated at least 6 inches (152 mm) above the roof or 3 inches (76 mm) above the anticipated snow accumulation, except that where a roof is to be used for any purpose other than weather protection, the vent extension shall be run at least 7 feet (2134 mm) above the roof. 
P3114.2 Installation of Air Admittance Valves. The air admittance valves shall be approved by the Code Official before installation. The valves shall not be used in new construction or additions where a vent through the roof is available. If the valve is approved, it shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of this section and the manufacturer's installation instructions. Air admittance valves shall be installed after the DWV testing required by Section 312.2 or 312.3 has been performed.
