Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, adopted May 8, 2018, enacted provisions designated as art. III, §§ 1-6. At the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been redesignated as art. VIII, §§ 38-311-38-316. 

Sec. 38-311. - Generally. 
(a)  Article III shall be fully set out herein. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the city from prosecuting a property owner, occupant, operator, and/or tenant for violating this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. III, § 1, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-312. - Debris, rodent harborages, weeds, and other nuisances. 
(a)  All premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of 12 inches. All noxious weeds shall be prohibited. Weeds shall be defined as all grasses, annual plants and vegetation, other than trees or shrubs provided. This term, however, shall not include cultivated flowers and gardens. 
(b)  All structures and exterior property shall be kept free from rodent harborage, infestation and the pooling of water. Where rodents are found, they shall be promptly exterminated by approved processes which will not be injurious to human health. After extermination, proper precautions shall be taken to eliminate rodent harborage and prevent reinfestation. Where pooled water is found, such water shall be removed so as to prohibit any further health or disease risk. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. III, § 2, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-313. - Notice. 
(a)  The city shall notify in writing the owner, operator, occupant, or tenant of any lot, place, or area within the city to cut, destroy, or remove any weeds, grass, trash, rubbish, garbage, rodent harborage, infestations, pooled water, or noxious matter found growing, lying or located on such owner or occupant's property or upon the sidewalk or street right-of-way abutting the property; or otherwise abate, destroy, or remove the nuisance(s) on the property cited in the notice, and that upon the failure of the owner or agent or occupant to do so the city will cause such weeds, grass, rubbish garbage, or noxious matter to be cut, destroyed or removed. 
(b)  Such notice shall be made in accordance with article III, section 38-61 above. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. III, § 3, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-314. - Clearing by city. 
    Upon failure, neglect, or refusal of any owner, agent, or occupant notified as provided in this article to cut, destroy, or remove weeds, grass, garbage, trash, rubbish, rodent harborage, infestation, pooled water, or noxious matter growing, lying or located upon such owner or occupant's property or upon the sidewalk, street, or any right-of-way abutting property, within seven calendar days of posting on the property as provided for in this article, the city may, in addition to any other penalties provided for in this article, pay for the cutting, destroying or removing of such weeds, grass, garbage, trash, rubbish, or noxious matter or effect the removal by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. III, § 4, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-315. - Costs of abatement/expenses. 
(a)  Upon completion of the work ordered by the city council the authorized city official shall compute the actual expense including, but not limited to, total wages paid, value of the use of equipment, advertising expenses, postage, materials purchased, and any other expense incurred by the city as a result of abating the nuisance. An itemized statement of such expenses shall be mailed to the last known address of the owner, operator, occupant, or tenant of the property. 
(b)  If the owner, operator, occupant, or tenant shall fail or refuse for a period of 30 days to pay off and discharge the expenses, the enforcing official shall report such failure to the city council at the next regular meeting following the expiration of that period. 
(c)  The city council shall hold a public hearing before causing the actual expense of the work to be levied as a special assessment against the property in addition to an administrative fee of 50 percent of the cost of the abatement. Notice of the public hearing shall be served as prescribed in article III, section 38-61. The itemized statement under subsection (a) of this section shall also give notice of the time and place of the public hearing. After the public hearing the city council may, by resolution, assess all or part of such expense against the property. 
(d)  Any assessment against property under this section shall not be final until seven calendar days after adoption by the city council. Once the assessment has become final, the city clerk shall have such resolution recorded in the office of the judge of probate in the county in which the property is located. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. III, § 5, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-316. - Appeals. 
(a)  In all cases, the property owner and/or occupant maintains a right to appeal any decision of the city council to the circuit court of the county in which the property is located as permitted under law. 
(b)  Any conviction in the municipal court may be appealed as provided under state law. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. III, § 6, 5-8-18) 
Secs. 38-317-38-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - ABANDONED AND INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES AS NUISANCES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, adopted May 8, 2018, enacted provisions designated as art. IV, §§ 1-7. At the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been redesignated as art. IX, §§ 38-331-38-337. 

Sec. 38-331. - Generally. 
(a)  Article III shall be fully set out herein. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the city from prosecuting a property owner, occupant, operator, and/or tenant for violating this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. IV, § 1, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-332. - Abandoned and inoperable motor vehicles declared nuisance. 
(a)  Except as provided for in other regulations, no more than one inoperable, wrecked, abandoned, or unregistered motor vehicle shall be parked, kept, or stored on any premises. No vehicle shall at any time be in a state of partial or substantial disassembly, disrepair, or in the process of being stripped or dismantled. Painting of vehicles is prohibited unless conducted inside an approved spray booth. All such vehicles shall be screened from view from all public or private street rights-of-way by virtue of storage within an enclosed building or being screened by privacy fencing, topography, and/or vegetation. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  A vehicle of any type is permitted to undergo major overhaul, including body work, provided that such work is performed inside a structure or similarly enclosed area designed and approved for such purposes; and 
(2)  Commercial property properly zoned for automobile repairs (i.e., body shops). 
(b)  No person shall park or cause to be parked any motor vehicle, recreational vehicle, trailer, ATV, motorcycle, boat, motorized equipment, golf cart, or any other item deemed in violation by the city's authorized city official or his designated agent upon any surface other than an improved surface as defined in the city's subdivision regulations. Further, all recreational vehicles or boats must be parked on an improved surface in an area located behind the front setback of said residential lot as defined in the city's zoning ordinance unless such vehicle or boat is being prepared for an imminent use in which case, such parking shall be limited to a period not to exceed 72 hours. For corner lots, said parking shall be provided in an area not located adjacent to any public street or right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. IV, § 2, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-333. - Notice. 
(a)  Any notice under this section shall be served as provided in article III, section 38-61. 
(b)  Upon service of the notice to abate the nuisance, the owner, operator, occupant, or tenant shall have seven calendar days to abate the nuisance by repairing the vehicle to make it operational or by removing the vehicle from the property. Failure of the owner, operator, occupant, or tenant to abate the nuisance within seven calendar days shall allow the authorized city official to begin abatement proceedings under this article. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to foreclose or limit the city's right to prosecute a property owner, occupant, operator, tenant, and owner of the abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle for violating this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. IV, § 3, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-334. - Removal of vehicle by towing and impounding-Authorized. 
(a)  As provided under federal and state law, as well as this article, any law enforcement officer is authorized to cause to be removed or tow an abandoned or inoperable vehicle following proof that notice was served on the owner, operator, occupant, or tenant of the property upon which the vehicle is unlawfully parked on a public street or public right-of-way or an abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle kept on a premises. 
(b)  Upon towing of an abandoned or inoperable vehicle, the law enforcement officer shall remove or caused to be removed the abandoned or inoperable vehicle to a garage or lot for storage. 
(c)  Prior to removing or causing to the abandoned and inoperable motor vehicle to be removed, the law enforcement officer shall make a reasonable effort to ensure the vehicle is not stolen or under a repossession claim by a lienholder. 
(d)  In the event of any the removal or towing of any vehicle as provided under this article, the law enforcement officer shall comply with state law. Within five calendar days of removing or causing an abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle to be removed as provided under this article, the law enforcement officer who removed the vehicle shall provide written notice of the removal to the owner(s) of record with the Alabama Department of Revenue, along with any lienholder if applicable, and the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. IV, § 4, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-335. - Authority to sell vehicle. 
    As provided under Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-13-3, the authorized city official is authorized to sell any vehicle impounded under this article as provided under state law. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. IV, § 5, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-336. - Assessments of costs; liens. 
(a)  Any special assessments or lien assessed against the real property upon which the abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle is located may be assessed as provided in article III, section 38-64 of this article. 
(b)  In the event an abandoned motor vehicle is auctioned or sold as provided under state law, if the owner of the property and the owner of the abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle are the same, any amount received from the auction or sale of the vehicle shall first be credited against the balanced owed of any special assessment or lien placed upon the real property from which the abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle was removed. Any remaining balance may be assessed as provided under Ala. Code § 32-13-6 (1975). 
(c)  In the event the owner of the abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle and the owner, occupant, operator, and/or tenant of the real property from which the abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle was removed, any amount received from the auction or sale of vehicle shall be assessed as provided under state law. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to waive any remedy the city may have at law or in equity. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. IV, § 6, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 38-337. - Appeals. 
(a)  In all cases, the property owner, occupant, operator, tenant, and owner of the abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle maintains a right to appeal any decision of the authorized city official to the city council. 
(b)  In all cases, the property owner, occupant, operator, tenant, and owner of the abandoned or inoperable motor vehicle maintains a right to appeal any decision of the city council to the circuit court of the county in which the real property is located as permitted under law. 
(c)  Any conviction in the municipal court may be appealed as provided under state law. 
(Ord. No. 2018-008-ADM, Art. IV, § 7, 5-8-18) 
Chapter 42 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; civil emergencies, ch. 22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Code adopted by reference. 
    The International Fire Code, 2003 Edition, including all appendices, except the recommended fees, is adopted by reference in this section as if fully set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-008 E&I, § 1, 2-10-98; Ord. No. 2003-046-EI, §§ 1, 3, 11-11-03; Ord. No. 2009-027-E+I, §§ 1, 2, 10-13-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-039-ADM, adopted Sept. 12, 2017, repealed Ord. No. 2009-027-E&I, adopted Oct. 13, 2009, which adopted by reference the International Fire Code, 2009 Edition. 
Sec. 42-2. - Establishment of fire lanes. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, any area (even though privately owned) provided in connection with a shopping center, other business establishment or public or semipublic building for the access, movement and parking of motor vehicles and which is open to the public generally for such use shall be termed a "public parking area." 
(b)  The chief of the fire department shall determine the need for fire lanes in any "public parking area," or over, across, or along any public road, for the purpose of providing adequate access for emergency vehicles, equipment and personnel to and from all buildings and structures adjacent to or served by such parking area or said public road, as provided in the Standard Fire Prevention Code, as the same may from time to time be amended. The city council shall establish fire lanes, upon recommendation of the fire chief and approval of the public safety committee, by adopting a resolution. 
(c)  The city shall designate, mark and otherwise appropriately identify the fire lanes hereby authorized. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park, stand, or stop a motor vehicle in any fire lane, which has been established and appropriately marked as a fire lane, or to place any item or structure in such a fire lane which in any way would block or interfere with access to the fire lane by any fire or other emergency vehicles, equipment or personnel. 
(e)  Any person or corporation found to be in violation of subsection (d) of this section shall upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 93-8 PS, §§ 1-3, 4-13-93; Ord. No. 96-003 PS, §§ 1-5, 2-13-96) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. 
Sec. 42-3. - Specifications and installation for new fire hydrants. 
(a)  All newly installed fire hydrants are required to have dual two-and-one-half-inch outlets with national standard threads and a five-inch storz connection at the pumper port for the pumper connection. 
(b)  The hydrant pumper connection shall be of one-piece design, compatible with five-inch storz hose coupling. The connection shall be an integral part of the fire hydrant assembly, resistant to tamper[ing] or removal by persons not familiar with the art of fire hydrant construction and must be furnished by the manufacturer or authorized distributor designated by the manufacturer. 
(c)  Fire hydrants shall have an auxiliary gate valve sufficient to permit repair or replacement without disruption of water services. 
(d)  Fire hydrants will be located at street intersections whenever practical. 
(e)  No person shall park any vehicle within ten feet of a fire hydrant. 
(f)  Fire hydrants shall be installed at a minimum every 750 feet in residential areas and every 300 feet in commercial and industrial areas. The water supply and pressure shall be sufficient to adequately serve the needed fire flow of the intended land use. 
(g)  All hydrants shall be completed, installed, and operational before beginning structural framing. 
(h)  Fire hydrants and fire mains are to meet the following standards AWWA C502, AWWA M31, AWWA MA7, and NFPA 1963. 
(Ord. No. 2004-009-PS, §§ 1(1)-1(9), 2-10-04) 
Sec. 42-4. - Opening burning. 
(1)  No person shall ignite, cause to be ignited, or maintain any open fire in the city limits of the City of Trussville, Alabama, except as expressly permitted herein. 
(a)  The following are permitted within the city: 
1.  Open fires for the cooking of food for human consumption if contained within personal barbeques and outdoor fireplaces. Only clean fuel not containing garbage, rubbish, rubber, plastics, or other refuse is permitted. Open fires are allowed for cooking food for periodic fundraising activities by not-for-profit charitable organizations and citywide events. this exception to the open burning prohibition does not include commercial food preparation facilities and their operation. 
2.  Fires to abate a fire hazard, as set and monitored by the fire department or fire district having jurisdiction over the area of the fire hazard. 
3.  Fires set in salamanders or other devices used by individuals for heating purposes, provided that warning fires are contained in a noncombustible container, and that materials burned are clean wood or fuel appropriate to the heating device, so as not to cause a public nuisance. No trash, garbage, rubber, plastic, or other refuse or synthetic materials may be burned. Warning fires shall not be used during conditions of weather where temperature, humidity, and wind are not so uncomfortable as to require artificial heating, as determined by local fire officials. Consideration will be given to ambient temperature and conditions when evaluating whether warning fires are required. 
(b)  The following are permitted within the city upon written notification to the Jefferson County Health Department (if property is located within Jefferson County), and to the Trussville Fire Department. 
1.  Fires for recreational or ceremonial purposes. Any person or organization intending to set a fire for recreational or ceremonial purposes shall provide written notification on a form provided by the Jefferson County Health Department (if the property is located within Jefferson County), no later than three working days prior to the event. The person or organization is also responsible for submitting written notice to the Trussville Fire Department and for obtaining any fire department permits required for such activities, no later than three working days prior to the event. 
2.  Fires for training personnel in the methods of fighting fires. Any person or organization desiring to set a fire for training personnel in the methods of fire fighting shall provide written notification to the Jefferson County Health Department (if the property is located within Jefferson County), and to the Trussville Fire Department at least ten days prior to the exercise. Training fires involving structures are subject to 40 CFR 61, subpart M, National Emission Standard for Asbestos, which requires inspection of the structure for asbestos and compliance with notification, emission control, and waste disposal procedures. 
a.  Notification for training fires shall include, at a minimum, the purpose of the training exercise, the types of materials to be burned, the location, date, time, and duration of the training exercise. 
b.  Structures used for training fires must be thoroughly inspected for the presence of asbestos containing materials, and said materials must be removed prior to the burning and demolition of the structure. Removal and disposal must be done by qualified personnel according to ADEM, EPA, and OSHA standards. All asphaltic materials such as roofing shingles, rubber, plastic, and other hazardous materials must be removed from the structure prior to burning. 
c.  The burning site or structure to be used in a training exercise designed to involve a large fire and/or a large volume of smoke shall meet the following minimum distance requirements: 
i.  At least 500 feet from the nearest inhabited dwelling. 
ii.  At least 150 feet from any public road. 
d.  This exemption from the open burning prohibition is intended only for official training exercises for firefighting personnel, and does not apply where the primary purpose of the fire is the destruction and removal of the structure. 
(c)  The following are permitted within the city only with express written authorization of the Jefferson County Health Department (if the property is located within Jefferson County), and by the Trussville Fire Department. 
1.  Fires for recognized agricultural, silvicultural, range and wildlife management practices. Agricultural burning shall be limited to commercial operations, not to include backyard gardens and lawns. 
2.  Fires for prevention or control of disease or pests, where no other practical or effective method of control is available. Any person or organization desiring to conduct an open burn for the prevention or control of disease or pests must submit written application to the Trussville Fire Department and the Jefferson County Health Department (if the property is located within Jefferson County), and obtain specific written authorization and/or permits required for such activities no later than three working days prior to the planned open burn. Such application shall be on forms prescribed for such purposes, if available, but at a minimum shall include the nature of the problem, the lack of alternative control methods, the procedures to be used, the date, time and location of the burn, and details on compliance with applicable regulations. Written authorization from the Jefferson County Health Department (if the property is located within Jefferson County), and the Trussville Fire Department (regardless of location) is specifically required prior to such burning. 
3.  Fires for disposing of vegetation. Any person or organization desiring to conduct an open burn to dispose of vegetation must submit written application to the Trussville Fire Department and the Jefferson County Health Department (if the property is located within Jefferson County), and obtain specific written authorization and/or permits required for such activities no later than three working days prior to the planned open burn. Such application shall be on forms prescribed for such purposes, if available, but at a minimum shall include the procedures to be used, the date, time and location of the burn, and details on compliance with applicable regulations. No written authorizations shall be issued during the months of May, June, July, August, and September of each year. Authorizations issued for this purpose in the former TSP nonattainment areas, or any future designated particulate nonattainment areas require strict adherence to the use of the air curtain incinerator (trench burner) method or equivalent. The following conditions shall be met: 
a.  All conditions on the authorization shall be met. 
b.  All materials to be burned shall be dry and in all respects be in a state to sustain good combustion. 
c.  The amount of dirt in the material to be burned shall be minimized. 
d.  Asphaltic materials, rubber, plastic, tires, demolition or construction waste, or any material other than vegetation shall not be burned. 
e.  Only trees and brush from the authorized clearing site shall be burned. Material shall not be imported from other sites. 
f.  Burning shall commence after 9:00 a.m., and no new material shall be charged to the fire after 3:00 p.m. on any day for which the authorization is valid. 
g.  The authorization may be revoked at any time by the Trussville Fire Department if any of the conditions of the authorization are violated, or if the burning at any time is deemed by the appropriate county health officer or his authorized representative to create, or has the potential to create, a public health nuisance. 
h.  The burning site shall meet the minimum distances specified in appendix A, table 1. 
i.  The Trussville Fire Department and/or the Alabama Forestry Commission shall be contacted before commencing any burning. 
(2)  Open burning shall be prohibited during the months of May, June, July, August, and September of each year, except as allowed or authorized by this section. 
(3)  The open burning of materials other than vegetation or untreated wood, except as otherwise provided for in this regulation, is at all times prohibited. 
(4)  Anyone igniting or maintaining an open fire allowed or authorized under the conditions above is responsible for compliance with all applicable fire control regulations, including but not limited to the obtaining permits or permission from the local fire jurisdiction, county health department, any other appropriate county officials or agencies, and the Alabama Forestry Commission. 
(5)  Open burning shall be conducted in compliance with this regulation as the same may be amended or revised. 
(6)  No open burning shall be allowed or authorized during any stage of an air-pollution episode, as declared by the Jefferson County Health Department or other agency having authority to declare such condition, or during any wildlife-hazard alerts issued by the Alabama Forestry Commission. All open burning shall be extinguished during any stage of an official air-pollution episode or wildlife-hazard alert. No open burning shall resume until the full termination of all episode stages or alerts. 
(7)  Notwithstanding the provisions set out above, the mayor of the city or the governor of the state may, by proclamation, issue a "no-burn" order for the city at any time deemed necessary and convenient to protect the public health and safety. 
(8)  No open burning site shall be left unattended, until the danger of reignition of the burned materials has passed. Fire control equipment shall be available on site for fire control during open burning. The burn attendant shall notify emergency response personnel in the event the open burn can no longer be controlled. 
Fire control equipment and/or tools must be adequate for the size of the open burn, and may include, the following or similar equipment and/or tools: 
(a)  Fire control equipment. Earth-moving equipment such as bulldozers, bobcats, and farm tractors with box blades. 
(b)  Hand tools. Rakes, shovels, flappers, and axes. 
(c)  Water and hoses. 
(9)  It shall be unlawful for any person in the vicinity of a fire to refuse to assist in fire control, if upon command by a firefighter or a police officer identified to him as such, he intentionally disobeys a reasonable order or regulation made in relation to the conduct of persons in the vicinity of a fire. 
(10)  Issuance of a burn permit for a specific site shall be considered prima-facia evidence that the person or entity to whom the permit was issued initiated the open burn and is responsible for compliance with this section. In the event an open burn is conducted without the required open burn permit, the property owner and/or his agent shall be held liable. 
(11)  Violation and penalties. 
(a)  Complaint procedure. Any citizen or any duly authorized municipal officer or employee wishing to make a complaint of a violation of this section may present himself or herself to the city magistrate to commence proceedings against the person in violation of the section. The complaining individual must swear under oath that the violation occurred and, if the magistrate has probable cause to believe that the offense constitutes a violation of this section, a summons and compliant may be issued to the individual. 
(b)  Issuance of summons and complaint by law enforcement officer. Any law enforcement officer of the city or any law enforcement officer of the state shall be authorized to issue a summons and complaint to any person charged with a violation of this section. Such summons and complaint procedure shall be in lieu of custodial arrest. 
(c)  Summons and complaint procedure by law enforcement officer. When a person is arrested for a violation of this section, the officer shall take the name and address of said person and any other information required by law and shall then issue the summons and complaint to the individual. Such individual shall not be taken into custody upon his written promise to appear in court at the designated time and place as evidenced by his signature. The signing of the summons and complaint shall serve as adequate bond for that individual. If the individual refuses to provide his or her personal written recognizance to appear by signing the summons and complaint, the authorized officer shall place him into custody and bring him before any officer or official authorized to approve bond. 
(d)  Settlement of charges. When a person is charged with a violation of this section, and when that person desires to waive legal process on the question of his innocence and plead guilty and voluntarily settle the charge, he or she may do so by pleading guilty and paying a sum to the municipal court magistrate. A plea of guilty shall be accepted by the magistrate only after the defendant had executed the notice and waiver of rights provision on the summons and complaint. Settlement fines will be assessed pursuant to the following schedule, which may be amended from time to time by the city council: 
1.  First violation within 12 months: $150.00 fine plus court costs; 
2.  Second violation within 12 months: Mandatory court appearance with the fine of no more than $500.00 plus costs and expenses to be assessed by the court and up to six months in jail at hard labor or both. 
For the purposes of the above schedule, the 12-month period will commence upon conviction or settlement of each violation. 
(e)  Payment of fine. The above fines and costs may be voluntarily paid to the municipal court magistrate not later than 72 hours before the court date shown on the summons and complaint. The magistrate shall be authorized to receive the amount in full settlement of the alleged offense and to give a receipt on the behalf of the city. If such payment is made, no further criminal prosecution for that specific violation shall be instituted or maintained in municipal court. All such payments must be made by personally appearing before said magistrate. 
(f)  Trial. Any offender wishing to plead guilty to a violation or who is otherwise required to appear in court for a violation of this section must execute a signature and written personal recognizance bond with the court magistrate assuring his or her appearance to answer the charge in municipal court of the city upon a date certain. 
(g)  Rights of the defendant. Any person or entity charged with violation of this section shall have the right to enter a plea of not guilty to any violation charged against said defendant and secure a trial in the municipal court. 
(h)  Failure to appear or properly settle charges. If the defendant fails to voluntarily settle his or her charges or fails to appear as specified in the summons and complaint, the municipal court judge may issue a warrant for his or her arrest commanding that he or she be brought before the court to answer the charge contained in the summons and complaint. In addition, any person who willfully violates his or her written promise or bond to appear shall be guilty of the separate offense of failure to appear, which is a misdemeanor, regardless of the disposition of the charge upon which he or she was originally arrested. 
(i)  Review of prior charges. The municipal court, upon conviction, shall have the duty and responsibility to consider all prior charges brought against the offender (whether settled or not) and will specifically consider all charges in the last twelve months. 
(j)  Additional power of the municipal court. The municipal judge shall have the following additional legal authority in connection with this section and the enforcement thereof. Said authority shall include the following: 
1.  Upon a sworn complaint being made by a citizen, a duly authorized municipal officer or employee, or a law enforcement officer of the city to the court clerk, the court shall be authorized to issue the following orders: 
a.  To assess all costs or expenses to the victim, including restitution, against said owner or responsible person. 
b.  To revoke the business privilege license of any entity responsible for the violation. 
c.  To increase the amount of the fine above that specified in the schedule, to the maximum allowed by law. 
2.  Upon the trial and conviction of a person or entity for a violation of any provision of this section, the municipal court shall have the authority to issue such other terms and conditions as the court may deem proper under the circumstances, in addition to all other power and authority conferred by law.

Sec. 42-5. - Multiple tenants served by a single automatic fire sprinkler riser. 
(a)  Any building(s) that has multiple tenants, that are served by a single automatic fire sprinkler riser, will meet the following conditions: 
(1)  The automatic fire sprinkler riser shall have a flow switch, tamper valve and exterior horn/strobe notification device as required by NFPA 13. 
(2)  The sprinkler system serving each tenant space shall have a dedicated flow switch, tamper valve, inspector's valve and drain (piped outside). 
(3)  Each flow switch and tamper valve shall be monitored by a fire alarm system. 
(4)  The fire alarm system shall identify each initiating device individually, so that an address and suite number can be sent to the monitoring station upon activation of any sprinkler head. 
(5)  Horn/strobe notification devices shall be installed in each tenant space, with spacing and locations in accordance to NFPA 72. 
(6)  All notification devices located between fire separation walls, shall activate together. 
(7)  Each tenant space shall have an exterior horn/strobe (rated for outdoor use) that operate only at the activation of the individual tenant's flow switch, to notify arriving fire department personnel of the location of the water flow. The location of the individual notification devices shall be determined by the fire marshal. 
(8)  All devices, equipment, locations and installation methods shall be installed in accordance to the applicable NFPA standard. 
(b)  No part of this section is intended to decrease any other applicable codes, standards or ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2016-035-ADM, § 1, 12-1-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-035-ADM, § 1, adopted Dec. 1, 2016, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 42-5 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 42-6. - [Combined department.] 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority contained in Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-140 et seq., the city has an existing paid fire department, Trussville Fire and Rescue, and has in the past utilized volunteer firefighters through a separate organization in accordance with city Ordinance No. 639. The city hereby repeals that ordinance. 
(b)  From this date forward, by the passing of this ordinance [from which this section derives], it is the intent of the city to have volunteer firefighters within the Trussville Fire and Rescue Department instead of utilizing, entering into or continuing any agreement with an outside volunteer entity. The organization and internal regulation of the department will continue to be governed by the provisions of this section, any future ordinances, current and existing policies and procedures, applicable laws and by such rules and regulations adopted by or used by the department, with the approval of the city council, except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance. 
(c)  The department continues to be authorized to adopt policies and procedures and rules and regulations for the control, management, government and regulation of the business and proceedings of the department. 
(Ord. No. 2017-017-PS, §§ 1-3, 3-28-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-017-PS, § 1, adopted March 28, 2017, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 42-6 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 42-7-42-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIREWORKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18. 

Sec. 42-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fireworks means any explosive composition or any substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose of producing an audible or visible effect by explosion, deflagration or detonation, and includes, but is not limited to, blank cartridges (except when used for bona fide sporting, industrial or commercial purposes) toy cannons in which explosives are used, flare balloons which require fire underneath to propel the balloon, firecrackers, sparklers (except as exempted in this section), torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, bombs or other fireworks containing any explosive compound or other devices containing any explosive substance. The term "fireworks," however, shall not include: 
(1)  Flares of the type used by railroads or any warning lights commonly known as red flares or marine distress signals of a type approved by the United States Coast Guard. 
(2)  Pistols containing 25/100 grains or less of explosive compound, toy pistols, toy guns or other devices in which paper caps containing 25/100 grains or less of explosive compound are used, provided the devices are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion. 
(3)  Sparklers and dipped sticks, when the total pyrotechnic composition does not exceed 100 grains each in weight and when the pyrotechnic composition containing any chlorate or perchlorate does not exceed five grams. 
(Ord. No. 235, § 1, 8-18-83) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 42-27. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-5. 
(Ord. No. 235, § 3, 8-18-83) 
Sec. 42-28. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, keep, possess, barter, exchange, give away or furnish at a public place or elsewhere, discharge, use or explode any firework within the city. 
    Exceptions to the foregoing prohibitions shall be available by permit issued by the city clerk of the City of Trussville on terms and conditions related to the health and welfare of the city when the use or display of fireworks is proposed in connection with an event of civic or public significance and when, in the judgement of the fire chief and chief of police, adequate provision has been made for safety and welfare of the public in connection with the use or display of fireworks. Authorization for the use or display of fireworks shall be according to application and permit forms approved by the mayor, with the advice of the fire chief and chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 235, § 2, 8-18-83; Ord. No. 98-018-PS, § 1, 5-12-98) 
Chapter 46 - FLOODS[1]
