ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC ORDER AND SAFETY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Offenses against public order and safety generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 58-56. - Discharge of firearms, air guns, similar devices. 
    No person shall discharge, shoot or fire any gun, firearm, air rifle, air pistol or similar device propelling or discharging pellets, shot, darts or any other projectile except in self-defense or by special permit from the city council, or unless exempted elsewhere in this article or as otherwise permitted or authorized by law. Nothing in this article shall prohibit the discharge of a gun, firearm, air rifle, air pistol or similar device by a person at any indoor firing range in the city, or on other property in the city, where such discharge is specially permitted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 51, § 1, 3-24-53; Ord. No. 177, § 1, 8-7-77; Ord. No. 2015-002-PS, 4-14-15) 
Sec. 58-57. - Possession of firearm. 
    No person shall possess or bear any gun or other firearm on any property of the city, whether leased or owned in fee simple, without a permit from the city council, or unless exempted as otherwise provided in this article or by law. 
(Ord. No. 177, § 2, 8-9-77) 
Sec. 58-58. - Carrying pistol on premises not his own prohibited; exception. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, no person shall carry a pistol about his person on private property not his own or under his control unless the person possesses a valid concealed weapon permit or the person has the consent of the owner or legal possessor of the premises; but this section shall not apply to any sheriff or his deputy or police officer of an incorporated town or city in the lawful discharge of the duties of his office, or to a United States marshal or his deputies, rural free delivery mail carriers in the discharge of their duties as such, bonded constables in the discharge of their duties as such, conductors, railway mail clerks and express messengers in the discharge of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 177, § 3, 8-9-77; Ord. No. 2015-002-PS, 4-14-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-52. 
Secs. 58-59-58-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES INVOLVING CURFEW 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-80. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular and words in the singular include the plural, words denoting masculine gender shall include the feminine gender. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not directory. The word "may" is always directory and not mandatory. 
    Accompanied means to be with or to be associated with under individualized supervision. 
    Custodian includes a "parent" as defined herein or an adult to whom the care or supervision of a minor has been temporarily delegated or assigned by the minor's custodial parent(s) or legal guardian. 
    Direct route means the shortest route of travel through a public place to reach a final destination, without any detour or stop. 
    Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that demands for immediate action. The term includes but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, an accident, or other situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Establishment means any privately owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
    Legal driving age. Sixteen years of age or older. 
    Minor means any person under 18 years of age, who has not been emancipated under Alabama law. 
    Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation owning, operating, managing or conducting any establishment. 
    Parent means a natural person having legal custody of a minor (a) as a natural or adoptive parent, (b) as a legal guardian, (c) as a person who stands in loco parentis, or (d) as a person to whom legal custody has been given by court order. 
    Public place means any public place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes but is not limited to roads, streets, highways, sidewalks, alleys, parks, playgrounds, public buildings, common areas of schools, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, shops and appurtenant open spaces or vacant lots. 
    Reasonable errand means the activity of a minor in a public place or establishment pursuant to a parent's or custodian's direction in order to accomplish an emergency mission or a legitimate family function in a normal and customary fashion considering the time of day, or going to or returning home from such activity without any detour or stop. 
    Remain means to linger or stay or fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer, the owner, operator, or other person in control of the premises. 
    Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
    Time of night means the prevailing standard of time whether central standard time or central daylight savings time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the city; prima facie the time then observed in the cities administrative offices and police department. 
    Years of age continue from one birthday to, but not including the day of, the next birthday. 
(Ord. No. 98-035-PS, § I, 10-27-98; Ord. No. 09-015-PS, § I, 5-12-09) 
Secs. 58-81-58-84. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OFFENSES; ENFORCEMENT; PENALTIES 

Sec. 58-85. - Offenses. 
(a)  Except as provided for in section 58-86 of this article, it shall be unlawful for a minor who is of legal driving age to be in a public place or in or upon the premises of an establishment: 
(1)  During Trussville City School System scheduled school hours; 
(2)  From 10:00 p.m. on any Sunday Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; 
(3)  From 11:00 p.m. on any Friday or Saturday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; 
(4)  Holidays shall be the same as Friday and Saturday unless the following day is a regularly scheduled school day. 
(b)  Except as provided for in section 58-86 of this article, it shall be unlawful for a minor who is under the age of 16 years to be in a public place or in or upon the premises of an establishment; 
(1)  During Trussville City School System scheduled school hours; 
(2)  Between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a parent or custodian to permit or by insufficient control to allow a minor under the parent's or custodian's care or custody to violate this article. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for an operator or establishment or an operator or establishment's agents or employees to knowingly permit a minor to remain in or upon the premises over which the operator has supervision, custody or control, in violation of this article. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for an operator or establishment within the Trussville City Limits to fail to conspicuously post and maintain on the business premises a current copy of the curfew hours. 
(f)  The provisions of this article shall apply with full force and effect to minors who are suspended, expelled or no longer currently enrolled in school. 
(g)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 98-035-PS, § II, 10-27-98; Ord. No. 09-015-PS, § II, 5-12-09) 
Sec. 58-86. - Exceptions. 
(a)  A minor shall be permitted to be in a public place or upon the premises of an establishment without regard to the provisions of subections 58-85(a) and (b) of this article if the minor is: 
(1)  accompanied by his parent, custodian, or other adult with charge and control over the minor; 
(2)  on a reasonable errand as directed by his parent or custodian; 
(3)  in a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  engaged in a lawful employment activity pursuant to his parent's or custodian's direction, or going to or returning home from such employment activity; 
(5)  involved in a legitimate emergency affecting the health, safety or welfare of the minor or the minor's family; 
(6)  on the sidewalk, right-of-way or property where he resides, or on private property on either side of or across the street from the place where the minor resides, provided that the adult owner or resident of that property has given permission for him to be there; 
(7)  attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the City of Trussville or another public body, civic organization, or other similar entity that takes responsibility for him, or going to or returning home from such activity, by a direct route without an unnecessary detour or stop; 
(8)  attending a bona fide work study program, or going to or returning home from such a program by a direct route without any unnecessary detour or stop and within one hour of the termination of the study program; 
(b)  Any operator or any establishment, or its agents or employees, who promptly notify a law enforcement agency that a minor is present in or upon the premises of an establishment in violation of this article and refused to leave shall not be found to have violated this article. 
(Ord. No. 98-035-PS, § III, 10-27-98; Ord. No. 09-015-PS, § III, 5-12-09) 
Sec. 58-87. - Penalties. 
(a)  When a police officer or other law enforcement officer observes or has probable cause to believe a violation has been committed, he shall temporarily detain the minor who is to be released only to the parent, custodian or family court. When more than one minor under control of the same parent or custodian is found in violation of the provisions of this section in the same act or incident, that parent or custodian shall be issued one citation. 
(b)  Upon receiving a citation for an initial violation of this article, the custodian, parent, operator or establishment shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00. 
(c)  Upon receiving a citation for a second or subsequent violation of this article, a court appearance shall be required and the custodian, parent, operator or establishment shall be punished by a fine of not less than $200.00 nor more than $500.00 or by imprisonment in the city jail for a period not exceeding six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(d)  The court may suspend or probate the sentence upon a conviction. As a condition of such suspension or probation, the court may order or require the performance of community service as a part of or in lieu of any penalty that may be imposed under this section. A parent or custodian may be required by the court to obtain counseling or attend classes or programs to improve parenting and child raising skills. 
(Ord. No. 98-035-PS, § IV, 10-27-98; Ord. No. 09-015-PS, § IV, 5-12-09) 
Sec. 58-88. - Nighttime violations. 
(1)  If a police officer or other law enforcement officer observes or has probable cause to believe that a minor is violating any provision of this article during the nighttime curfew hours as herein established, the parent or custodian shall be issued a citation and the officer shall; 
(a)  Ascertain the identification of the minor's parent(s), make reasonable efforts to notify the minor's parent(s) that the minor is in violation of this article and make reasonable efforts to take the minor home to his parent(s) who reside within the city limits or police jurisdiction of the City of Trussville; 
(b)  In the event that custody of the minor cannot be delivered to the minor's parent(s) due to the absence of the parent(s), abuse is alleged or it is reasonably suspected, or said parent(s) reside outside the jurisdiction of the municipal court, or the parent(s) refuse to take custody of said minor, the officer shall transport said minor to the Jefferson County Family Court in accordance with Alabama law; 
(c)  If a minor remains in law enforcement custody more than two hours and reasonable efforts have been made to notify his parent(s) of his detention, the minor shall be delivered to the Jefferson County Family Court in accordance with Alabama law; 
(d)  If the officer observes or has probable cause to believe the minor has also committed a criminal offense, the officer shall forthwith take the minor into law enforcement custody in accordance with Alabama law. 
(Ord. No. 98-035-PS, § V, 10-27-98) 
Sec. 58-89. - Daytime violations. 
(1)  If a police officer or other law enforcement officer observes or has probable cause to believe that a minor is violating any provision of this article during the daytime curfew hours as herein established, the parent or custodian shall be issued a citation and the officer shall; 
(a)  Ascertain the identification of the minor's parent(s) and transport the minor to the appropriate school to determine if the minor is lawfully enrolled in the Jefferson County School System. If said minor is lawfully enrolled, the officer shall deliver custody of said minor to the appropriate school official; if the minor is lawfully enrolled in a school system outside the city limits of Trussville, the officer will make reasonable efforts to deliver the minor to the appropriate school authorities. 
(b)  If the said minor is not lawfully enrolled in school, or the school system is outside the city limits of Trussville and the minor cannot reasonably be transported to the school authorities the officer shall transport said minor to the Jefferson County Family Court; 
(c)  If the officer observes or has probable cause to believe the minor has also committed a criminal offense, the officer shall take the minor into law enforcement custody in accordance with Alabama law. 
(Ord. No. 98-035-PS, § VI, 10-27-98) 
Sec. 58-90. - Enforcement against adults. 
(1)  If a police officer or other law enforcement officer observes or has probable cause to believe an adult is violating any provision of this article, the officer shall issue a written citation. 
(2)  If the minor's parent(s) is not available to be cited, the officer shall swear to a complaint. The magistrate, upon determining cause, shall issue a summons. 
(3)  A noncustodial arrest shall be attempted. However, if the adult violator refuses to sign the citation, a custodial arrest shall be effected. 
(Ord. No. 98-035-PS, § VII, 10-27-98) 
Secs. 58-91-58-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PROSTITUTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-100. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to this article: 
    Advance prostitution. A person advances prostitution if, acting other than as a prostitute or a patron of a prostitute, he or she knowingly causes or aids a persons to commit or engage in prostitution, procures or solicits patrons for prostitution, provides persons or premises for prostitution purposes, operates or assists in the operation of a house of prostitution or a prostitution enterprise. 
    Deviate [deviant] sexual intercourse. Any act of sexual gratification between persons not married to each other involving the sex organs of one person and the mouth or anus of another. 
    Profit from prostitution. A persons profits from prostitution if, acting other than as a prostitute receiving compensation for personally rendered prostitution services, he or she accepts or receives money or other property pursuant to a prior agreement with any person whereby her or she participates or is to participate in the proceeds of prostitution activity. 
    Prostitution. Prostitution shall mean the commission by a person of any natural or unnatural sexual act, deviate [deviant] sexual intercourse, or sexual contact for monetary consideration or other thing of value. 
    Sexual conduct. Sexual intercourse, deviate [deviant] sexual intercourse, or sexual contact. 
    Sexual contact. Any touching of the sexual or other intimate parts of a person not married to the person so acting, done for the purpose of gratifying the sexual desire of either party. 
    Sexual intercourse. Sexual intercourse has its ordinary meaning and occurs upon any penetration, however slight: emission is not required. 
(Ord. No. 2000-020-PS, § 1, 7-11-00) 
Secs. 58-101-58-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OFFENSES AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 58-106. - Offenses and prohibitions. 
    This article shall establish as an offense the crimes of prostitution, patronizing a prostitute, soliciting prostitution, promoting prostitution, permitting prostitution, aiding in the commission of prostitution and transporting for the purpose of prostitution. In any prosecution for prostitution or patronizing a prostitute or soliciting prostitution, the sex of the parties or prospective parties to sexual conduct engaged in, contemplated, or solicited is immaterial, and it is no defense that: (a) both parties were of the same sex; or (b) that the person who received, agreed to receive, or solicited a fee was a male and the person who paid or agreed or offered to pay the fee was a female; or (c) that the person who received, agreed to receive, or solicited a fee was a female and the person who paid or agreed or offered to pay the fee was a male. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or to agree or offer to engage in sexual intercourse or participate in any natural or unnatural sexual act, deviate [deviant] sexual intercourse, or sexual contact for monetary consideration or other thing of value and give or accept monetary consideration or other thing of value in furtherance of the agreement. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit, compel, or coerce any person to have sexual intercourse or participate in any natural or unnatural sexual act, deviate [deviant] sexual intercourse, or sexual contact for monetary consideration or other thing of value. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a person to do any of the following: 
1.  Pursuant to a prior understanding, he or she pays a fee to another person as compensation for that person or a third person having or engaging in sexual conduct with him or her. 
2.  He or she pays or agrees to pay a fee to another person on an understanding that in return that person or a third person will engage in sexual conduct with him or her in return for a fee. 
3.  He or she solicits or requests another person to engage in sexual conduct with him or her in return for a fee. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly do any of the following: 
1.  Cause or aid a person to commit or engage in prostitution; 
2.  Procure or solicit patrons for prostitution; 
3.  Provide persons or premises for prostitution purposes; 
4.  Receive or accept money or [any] other thing of value pursuant to a prior agreement with any person whereby he or she participates or is to participate in the proceeds of any prostitution activity; 
5.  Operate or assist in the operation of a house of prostitution or a prostitution enterprise. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any bellhop, elevator operator, desk clerk, servant, or employee of a hotel, motel, inn, boardinghouse, apartment house, or any lodging place of like kind for the purpose of or in furtherance of unlawful sexual misconduct or prostitution to: 
1.  Conduct any person to the room of any guest or occupant of the place; 
2.  Carry any note or message to or from a person, a guest, or occupant of the place. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or manager of any hotel, motel, inn, boardinghouse, apartment house, or any lodging place or like kind to employ a person who has been convicted of aiding or abetting prostitution. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any common carrier or for the driver in charge of any taxicab or other public service vehicle to knowingly transport or aid or abet in the transportation of any person to or from any place in the city for the purpose of prostitution. 
(Ord. No. 2000-020-PS, § 2, 7-11-00) 
Sec. 58-107. - Enforcement. 
    Violation of the terms of this article shall be punishable by fine up to $500.00 or imprisonment at hard labor for up to six months or both. 
(Ord. No. 2000-020-PS, § 3, 7-11-00) 
Chapter 62 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Parks, playgrounds and other recreational and athletic areas and facilities, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-210 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Vehicles in parks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive any vehicle not previously authorized in any public park, except upon the roads, driveways or parking areas therein during authorized times, or to park any vehicle not previously authorized in any public park, except in designated parking areas therein set apart for such use during authorized times. 
(Ord. No. 195, § 1, 5-2-78; Ord. No. 94-012 PS, § 1, 3-8-74; Ord. No. 94-16 PS, § 1, 3-8-94) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. 
Secs. 62-2-62-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK AND RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-216 et seq. 
State Law reference- Public park and recreation boards generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-60-1 et seq. 

Sec. 62-31. - Name. 
    The advisory board of the City of Trussville, established under Ordinance No. 455, shall continue to be known as "The Park and Recreation Board of the City of Trussville, Alabama." 
(Ord. No. 455, § I, 9-10-85; Ord. No. 2001-008-P&R, § 1, 3-27-01) 
Sec. 62-32. - Membership. 
    The board shall consist of eight members and up to two advisory members. 
(a)  Members shall be appointed by majority vote of the city council. Terms of office shall be four years and shall be staggered to allow for two vacancies to occur on February 28 of each calendar year. As terms of members expire, their successors shall be appointed for terms of four years each. Vacancies in unexpired terms shall be filled by the city council in the same manner as original appointments are made; replacement appointees shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term to which they are appointed. 
(b)  Advisory members shall be appointed by majority vote of the park and recreation board as deemed appropriate by the board to lend expertise and guidance. Terms of office shall be two years with terms to expire on February 28. Vacancies in unexpired terms shall be filled by the park and recreation board in the same manner as original appointments are made; replacement appointees shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term to which they are appointed. Advisory members shall not be voting members of the park and recreation board. 
(c)  Members and advisory members may be reappointed. Members and advisory members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in the service of the board with approval of the city council. Members may be removed for cause by the mayor. Further, any member missing four consecutive monthly meetings may be removed by the mayor. 
(d)  The councilperson over parks and recreation shall attend board meetings and report the actions of the board to the city council as necessary. The council liaison shall not be a voting member of the board. The term of the council liaison shall coincide with his or her term of office. 
(Ord. No. 455, § III, 9-10-85; Ord. No. 2001-008-P&R, § 4, 3-27-01) 
Sec. 62-33. - Organization. 
    The board is authorized to appoint a chairperson and vice-chairperson and to appoint such officers and adopt such bylaws and procedures as it may deem expedient. 
(Ord. No. 455, § IV, 9-10-85; Ord. No. 2001-008-P&R, § 5, 3-27-01) 
Sec. 62-34. - Meetings. 
    The park and recreation board shall convene for regular meetings not less than monthly and as frequently as may be necessary as called by the chairperson or vice-chairperson. Attendance by five board members, not including advisory members, shall constitute a quorum of the board. Minutes shall be kept of all meetings of the park and recreation board, and shall be permanently maintained. 
(Ord. No. 455, § V, 9-10-85; Ord. No. 2001-008-P&R, § 6, 3-27-01) 
Sec. 62-35. - Purposes; authority. 
    The board herein established is created for the following purposes: 
(a)  To advise and promote the maintenance and improvement of public parks in the City of Trussville; 
(b)  To identify recreational needs and interests of the community and to develop appropriate and necessary means of meeting such needs and interests; 
(c)  To generate public and municipal interest in and support of board-sponsored park and recreational programs, projects, and activities; 
(d)  To develop and recommend policies for the use of recreational facilities and the community center. 
(Ord. No. 455, § VI, 9-10-85; Ord. No. 2001-008-P&R, § 2, 3-27-01) 
Sec. 62-36. - Annual report. 
    Each year the board shall make a formal, comprehensive report to the city council on its goals, activities, and accomplishments by August 31. 
(Ord. No. 455, § VI, 9-10-85; Ord. No. 2001-008-P&R, § 7, 3-27-01) 
Sec. 62-37. - Limitations. 
    The board shall be empowered to do all things necessary and appropriate to accomplish its purposes subject, however, to the following limitations: 
(a)  The board shall have no authority to incur any liability or to bind the city except by prior express approval of the city council as reflected in the minutes of the city council; 
(b)  Board actions shall be subject to city council approval. 
(Ord. No. 2001-008-P&R, § 3, 3-27-01) 
Chapter 66 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, adopted Feb. 27, 2018, repealed ch. 66 in its entirety. Arts. I-IV of said ordinance enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Former ch. 66, §§ 66-1, 66-31-66-40, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 204, §§ 1-3, adopted Aug. 7, 1979; and Ord. No. 230, §§ 1-9, adopted Nov. 18, 1982. 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Itinerate vendors to file bond, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-23-24; license required, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 40-12-139, 40-12-174. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Statement of findings and purpose. 
(a)  The city council finds an influx of groups and individuals going door-to-door peddling and soliciting throughout the corporate limits. 
(b)  Further, the city council finds many of these individuals do not reside within the corporate limits nor do the entities represented have any affiliation or place of business within the corporate limits. 
(c)  Further, the city council, after consultation with the Trussville Police Department, finds an increase in the reports of burglary, theft, breaking and entering motor vehicles, and reports of suspicious activities throughout the corporate limits. 
(d)  To preserve the safety and welfare of its residences, the city council declares the purpose of enacting these regulations is to require persons or organizations to register and obtain a permit, in advance, to sell or solicit within the corporate limits and by requiring such persons or organizations to supply information relating to their identities and purposes in connection therewith. 
(e)  The city is authorized to regulate peddlers, solicitors, and itinerant vendors within the its corporate limits. 
(f)  The provisions within this article shall be interpreted to effectuate the purposes herein in the broadest sense permissible under law. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. I, § A, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    Charity or non-profit organization means any enterprise whose primary purpose is to pursue social, charitable, or other benevolent activities and classified as a tax-exempt organization under applicable provisions of the United States Internal Revenue Code. 
    City refers to the City of Trussville, Alabama, a municipal corporation formed under the laws of the State of Alabama. 
    Entity means any business, corporation, limited liability companies, sole proprietorship, or any other body, regardless if those are for profit or otherwise, that is not a natural person. 
    Panhandling means any solicitation made in person upon any street, sidewalk, public way, or public place, or upon the premises of any business establishment or other private property that is routinely or customarily frequented by the general public, requesting an immediate donation of money or other thing of value for oneself or another person or entity. 
    Person means a natural person. 
    Police department and chief of police means the City of Trussville, Alabama, Police Department and the individual who occupies the position of City of Trussville Chief of Police. 
    Registrant or registered solicitor means any person or entity who is subject to this article and who has obtained a valid certificate of registration from the City of Trussville, Alabama. 
    Residence means any living unit contained within any building or structure that is occupied by any person as a dwelling consistent with the definition of "residence" as defined in the zoning ordinance of the City of Trussville, Alabama. 
    Solicitation means any of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the sale or exchange of goods, wares, merchandise, or perishables of any kind, for any kind of remuneration or consideration, regardless of whether advance payment is sought; 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers to apply for or to purchase insurance, publications or subscriptions to publications; 
(3)  Seeking to obtain contributions or donations of anything of value for the benefit of any individual, association, organization, corporation, or program; 
(4)  Seeking to obtain orders or prospective customers for goods or services; 
(5)  Requesting monies or contributions of other goods or services for any charity or non-profit organization or for-profit organization or any other type or form of entity; and 
(6)  Distributing handbills, written advertisements, or publications. 
    Solicitor means a person or entity engaged in the activities defined in this article as soliciting. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. I, § B, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-3. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any provision of this article may be issued a citation by any law enforcement officer having jurisdiction within the corporate limits. If an individual is cited, he or she shall be required to appear before the municipal court of the City of Trussville. 
(b)  Upon conviction of any violation of this chapter, the person shall be punished as provided in section 1-5 of this Code of Ordinances. Such punishment provides for a fine not to exceed $500.00 or six months imprisonment in the city jail or any combination thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. I, § C, 2-27-18) 
Secs. 66-4-66-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REQUIREMENT TO REGISTER 

Sec. 66-21. - Registration requirements for door-to-door solicitation. 
(a)  Registration. All persons desiring to engage in soliciting at residences within the corporate limits shall apply to the chief of police for a certificate of registration. Each certificate of registration shall be valid for one, 30-day period. Following the expiration of the certificate of registration, any entity or person may reapply to the chief of police for a certificate of registration. There shall be no limits in the number of applications an entity or person may obtain so long as all conditions are satisfied as discussed within this article. The certificate, executed by the chief of police or his designee, shall be maintained by the police department and a legible copy shall be carried by the registrant at all times while soliciting. Upon request for inspection by an occupant of a residence or a police officer or a city license and tax examiner while the registered solicitor is transacting his business or seeking to transact his business at any residence, the registrant shall show his or her copy of the registration certificate. In addition to the registration fee, all other city ordinances levying business license fees and other license fees and taxes are applicable, including the business license ordinance requiring transient vendors to obtain a business license. 
(b)  Application for certificate. The city shall provide a standard form for use for registration of solicitors. The applicant for the registration certificate shall state in writing upon his or her oath or affirmation that the information is truthfully provided to the best of his or her knowledge and belief. The applicant shall supply with or upon the registration form the following information: 
(1)  Applicant's true, correct, and legal name and the name of the organization for which he/she will be soliciting; 
(2)  Address and phone number of applicant's home and applicant's place of business; 
(3)  Names and addresses of the corporate officers or the partners and the managers, if any, of the entity for which the applicant will be soliciting; 
(4)  The purpose for which soliciting will be done; 
(5)  A brief description of the method of presentation that will be made; 
(6)  Whether a permit, license, or certificate of registration from any city in connection with soliciting has ever been revoked, explaining the circumstances; 
(7)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a misdemeanor or a felony; 
(8)  Documentation that the person is authorized to solicit for the organization; and 
(9)  Two passport-sized photos taken within 60 days of application. 
(c)  Non-endorsement. In addition, the applicant shall certify on the application form that if his or her registration is granted, he or she will not state, imply, or represent to any person that the issuance of the certificate is an endorsement by the city of the product, service, solicitor, or the organization represented by the solicitor. 
(d)  Proof of identification required. No certificate of registration shall be issued except upon proof of identification, including a photograph of the applicant, in one of the following forms: 
(1)  A valid driver's license of any state in the United States. 
(2)  A valid United States Uniform Service Identification. 
(3)  A valid passport. 
(4)  A valid identification issued by any agency of a state for the purpose of identification of the holder. 
(e)  Registration complete with issuance. Registration shall be complete when the police chief issues the certificate of registration, which shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. 
(f)  Form of certificate. Each certificate shall be numbered, shall list the name of the individual solicitor and of all organizations on whose behalf he or she is authorized to solicit, the date on which the certificate will expire, and shall be dated and signed by the police chief or his designee. 
(g)  Maintenance of registry. The police department shall maintain, available for public inspection during normal business hours, a record of every application received and acted upon, together with any information pertaining thereto, all certificates of registration issued, and all denials of applications. Each application shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and each certificate issued shall be assigned a number exclusive to the registrant. 
(h)  Expiration. Certificates shall be valid for one month and shall expire at 11:59 p.m. on the date one month from the date of issuance. 
(i)  Non-transferability. Certificates of registration shall be issued only in the name of the applicant and the firms, corporations or associations on whose behalf he or she is authorized to solicit. Each natural person soliciting must obtain a certificate of registration. Certificates shall be nontransferable. It shall be a violation for a solicitor whose certificate authorizes soliciting on behalf of a firm named in the certificate to solicit on behalf of any other firm, organization, or association or for any purpose other than that specified on the application. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. II, § A, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-22. - Registration-Exemptions. 
(a)  The registration provisions of this article do not apply to the following: 
(1)  Persons making solicitations solely for a church, religious organization or charitable organization, including any unincorporated association or corporation under the supervision and control of any church, a charitable organization or religious organization, if the church or organization is tax exempt under the provisions of the United States Internal Revenue Code. 
(2)  Students soliciting contributions to finance extracurricular academic, social, athletic, artistic, scientific, or cultural programs, provided that the solicitation and its purpose have been approved by the principal, president, or chief administrator of the school that the students attend and said approval has been filed in writing with the city. 
(3)  Persons canvassing for the purpose of distributing political literature or materials on behalf of a political party, candidate, or public issue or introducing themselves as supporters of a candidate, political party, cause, or issue. 
(4)  Persons making solicitations solely for a nationally recognized youth organization such as the YMCA, YWCA, scouting, or boys' and girls' clubs. 
(b)  All other provisions of this article apply to those who qualify for an exemption. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. II, § B, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-23. - Revocation of certificate. 
    Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the police department if the registrant is convicted of a violation of this article, if the registrant has falsified the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration. Notice of revocation shall be given to the registrant by personal service or by certified mail to the address listed on the application. Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the certificate of registration shall become null and void and shall remain so unless the revocation is ordered rescinded by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. II, § C, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-24. - Appeal. 
    An applicant whose registration was denied or registrant whose certificate was revoked shall have the right to appeal to the city clerk. An applicant shall also have the right to appeal any adverse decision of the city clerk to the city council. Any appeal must be demanded in writing sent by certified mail to the city clerk within seven calendar days of the decision that is being appealed. The right of appeal to the city council is not in derogation of any other rights in law or equity the applicant might have. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. II, § D, 2-27-18) 
Secs. 66-25-66-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PROHIBITED ACTS 

Sec. 66-41. - Deceptive soliciting practices prohibited. 
(a)  No solicitor or canvasser shall intentionally or recklessly make any materially false or fraudulent statement in the course of soliciting. 
(b)  No solicitor shall use a fictitious name, an alias, or any name other than his or her true, correct, and legal name. 
(c)  No solicitor shall represent, directly or by implication, that the city or any other governmental entity endorses the solicitation or that the granting of a certificate of registration implies any endorsement of the solicitor's product or service or of the individual solicitor. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. III, § A, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-42. - Registrations of felons prohibited. 
    No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of a federal or state felony. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. III, § B, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-43. - Residential notices for "No Solicitation." 
(a)  Any occupant of a residence or occupants of a multi-family dwelling who desire(s) not to have solicitors call on said residence(s) shall give notice of the desire to refuse solicitors by displaying a clearly visible weatherproof placard with an approved design by the ordinance as shown by picture with dimensions of 12 inches by 12 inches totaling 144 square inches stating: 
"No Soliciting" Ordinance # 2018-027 Admin (as example) which shall be posted on or near the main entrance of the private property and not within the public right-of-way. The sign shall have a black decorative background with white lettering and mounted on a mono pole no higher than 41/2; feet above ground to top of the sign. 
"NO SOLICITING"

ORDINANCE # 2018-027

ADMIN

CITY OF TRUSSVILLE 
(b)  Residents of a residential subdivision may indicate their desire not to have solicitors call on any residences in that subdivision by giving notice to the police department by petition from the majority residents of their subdivision or homeowners' association of the desire to refuse solicitors by displaying a clearly visible weatherproof placard with an approved design by the ordinance as shown by picture with dimensions of 18 inches by 18 inches totaling 324 square inches stating: 
"NO SOLICITING" Ordinance # 2018-027 Admin (as example) which shall be posted on or near the main entrance of the subdivision on private property and not within the public right-of-way unless written permission is granted by the city engineer. The sign shall have a black decorative background with white lettering and mounted on mono pole no higher than 41/2; feet above ground to top of sign. 
"NO SOLICITING"

CITY OF TRUSSVILLE 
(c)  The display of said placard shall be deemed to constitute notice to any solicitor that the inhabitant of the residence does not desire to invite solicitors. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. III, § C, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-44. - Panhandling prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in panhandling. 
(b)  A person is not considered to be panhandling if: 
(1)  The person or entity complies with the registration requirements as stated in this article; 
(2)  Is exempt from the registration requirements of this article; or 
(3)  Receives written permission from a business or land owner to solicit donations while on that businesses' or land owner's property. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. III, § D, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-45. - Retailing merchandise from vehicles; solicitation within rights-of-way. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle or other vehicle for the purpose of making retail sales of merchandise from such vehicle while so parked within rights-of-way. This section, however, shall not be construed to limit the right to park motor vehicles on the portions of the streets for the purpose of unloading merchandise sold at wholesale for delivery to duly licensed retail stores, nor to limit the right to park motor vehicles and other vehicles on the portions of the streets for any other purpose except the purpose of making retail sales of merchandise from such vehicles while so parked. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to solicit or otherwise make retail sales of any merchandise upon the sidewalks and in or upon the parkways running along or abutting upon any street except as allowed by the zoning ordinance of the city and after being duly licensed. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. III, § E, 2-27-18) 
Secs. 66-46-66-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SOLICITORS-DUTIES AND RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 66-61. - Duties of solicitors. 
(a)  Every solicitor shall, upon entering premises on which a residence is located, examine the main entrance to the premises for any "no soliciting" placard, and if one is posted, desist in any efforts to solicit or to leave any literature concerning the solicitation at that residence. Possession of a certificate of registration does not relieve any solicitor of this duty. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to appear at any private residence and canvass or solicit whereon a placard bearing the words "no soliciting" or words of similar import is posted for public view. Possession of a certificate of registration does not relieve any solicitor of this duty. 
(c)  Any solicitor who is asked to leave any residence by the occupant shall immediately and peacefully depart. Possession of a certificate of registration does not relieve any solicitor of this duty. 
(d)  Every solicitor shall at all times, while exercising the privilege in the city incident to the permit, carry upon his person his permit and the same shall be exhibited by such person at all times while soliciting and whenever he is requested to do so by any police officer or by any person who is solicited. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. IV, § A, 2-27-18) 
Sec. 66-62. - Time and day restrictions on soliciting. 
(a)  It is a violation of this article for any person, whether registered or not, to solicit any person at his or her residence before 9:00 a.m. or after 7:00 p.m. local time, unless the solicitor has express permission from the resident to do so. 
(b)  It is also a violation of this article for any person, whether registered or not, to solicit any person at his or her residence on Sunday. 
(Ord. No. 2018-005-ADM, Art. IV, § B, 2-27-18) 
Chapter 70 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes:
