ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AND ZONING BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-216 et seq. 

Sec. 70-31. - Created. 
    There is created a planning commission of the city, to be designated the planning and zoning board of the city. 
(Ord. No. 18, § 1, 5-27-48) 
Sec. 70-32. - Powers, duties. 
    The planning and zoning board shall be and is hereby vested with all the powers and rights, and charged with all the duties, vested in and imposed upon planning commissions by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-1 et seq., and any and all other statutes of the state relating thereto. 
(Ord. No. 18, § 2, 5-27-48) 
Sec. 70-33. - Jurisdiction. 
(1)  Jurisdiction reaffirmed. The territorial jurisdiction of the municipal planning commission of the city shall include all land lying within five miles of the corporate limits of Trussville and not located within any other municipality, as provided by state law. 
(2)  Limitations on the exercise of said jurisdiction. The jurisdiction of the planning commission provided for by state law to regulate subdivisions outside the city limits shall be exercised only in areas of unincorporated St. Clair County, Alabama, lying within one and one-half miles of the city limits of Trussville, and shall not be exercised in unincorporated Jefferson County, Alabama, inasmuch as Jefferson County currently regulates subdivisions and building in those areas. 
(3)  Stormwater detention ordinances to be enforced outside city limits. The planning commission is fully authorized to apply the stormwater detention ordinance and the standards contained therein as part of its subdivision regulations, as are adopted by the planning commission, and to apply those standards throughout its extraterritorial jurisdiction, as may be limited herein, if so adopted. 
(4)  Maximum jurisdiction allowed by law. The jurisdiction and authority of the planning commission and city officials to regulate, control, and enforce the applicable rules and regulations of the City of Trussville, Alabama, within St. Clair County shall be the maximum provided for and allowed by law, as same may be amended. 
(5)  Modification of existing ordinances, resolutions or regulations. To the extent that other ordinances, resolutions, or regulations refer to the jurisdiction of the planning commission in terms of the city or municipal limits of the city, they are hereby amended to include within said jurisdiction the territories outside the city limits described heretofore. 
(6)  Zoning ordinance to be enforced within city limits. The provision of this section shall in no way extend the application of the city's zoning ordinance beyond that permitted by law, and the extra-territorial jurisdiction of the planning commission or the building official shall not be based on the city's authority to enact zoning regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2004-021-PZ, §§ 1-6, 4-13-04) 
Secs. 70-34-70-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-216 et seq. 

Sec. 70-56. - Created. 
    Pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-80 et seq. there is hereby created a board of zoning adjustment for the city to consist of five members, to be appointed for the terms and in the manner set forth in such statute. 
(Ord. No. 80, § 1, 8-9-60) 
Sec. 70-57. - Powers. 
    The board of zoning adjustment is authorized and empowered as follows: to hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of this article or of any ordinance adopted pursuant thereto; to hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of the ordinance upon which such board is required to pass under such ordinance; to authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variance from the terms of the ordinance as will not be contrary to the public interest, where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of the ordinance will result in unnecessary hardship, and so that the spirit of the ordinance shall be observed and substantial justice done. In exercising the abovementioned powers the board may, in conformity with the provisions of this article, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination as ought be made, and, to that end shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken. 
(Ord. No. 80, § 2, 8-9-60) 
Chapter 74 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Authority regarding incinerators and garbage generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-135; solid waste generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Placement of yard trash and debris. 
(a)  In order to prevent impediment to flow or clogging of drainage structures persons shall not place grass clippings, limbs, logs, trash, or debris in the gutter line of any city street. 
(b)  Limbs and brush shall be separated from grass clippings and leaves. Limbs shall be cut not exceeding eight feet in length or 100 pounds in weight. All grass clippings shall be placed in bags. 
(c)  Limbs, brush, grass clippings and leaves are to be placed behind the curbline or on the bank. No grass clippings, limbs, brush, leaves or debris shall be placed in the gutter or ditch line. The street maintenance crews of the city will effect pickup as soon as practical. 
(d)  Commercial tree trimmers and tree surgeons are required to remove and properly dispose of all limbs and trees cut by them. 
(e)  Rocks, dirt, construction debris, discarded household items, furnishings or fixtures, lawn furniture, rugs, metals, tires and similar items are not picked up by the city maintenance crews and therefore must be properly disposed of in the Eastern Area Landfill. 
(Ord. No. 89-54 P & Z, § 2, 9-26-89) 
Secs. 74-2-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTERING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 58. 

Sec. 74-31. - Prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or cause or allow to be thrown or placed on any sidewalk, street, alley or driveway or on any public property, or on private property within 50 feet of a sidewalk or street in the city, any paper, litter, rubbish, debris, filthy or odoriferous objects, substance or other trash of any kind or nature, including, but not limited to, bottles, glassware or glass of any description, broken or unbroken; any cans or other metal objects; stones; trash; paper; cinders; planks; shingles and any hazardous obstruction tending to injure any person, animal, vehicle or tire using any sidewalk, street, alley, driveway or property, except that such may be placed in a proper receptacle or at a location near the pavement edge, but in no case in the gutter or ditchline, for weekly pickup. 
(b)  Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be fined not less than $25.00 and not more than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 215, § 1, 4-6-81; Ord. No. 2005-024-PS, §§ 1, 2, 6-14-05) 
Secs. 74-32-74-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COLLECTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority regarding waste collection and disposal generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-3. 

Sec. 74-56. - Service guidelines. 
(a)  A mandatory garbage collection, hauling, and disposal service and a curbside recycling program shall be conducted and performed within the City of Trussville. Alabama (hereinafter referred to as the "city"), by an independent waste contractor (hereinafter referred to as the "contractor") to be determined through the prescribed bid process. 
(b)  Collection rates shall be determined by competitive bid prices received with provisions for periodic rate adjustments during the life of the three-year contract as negotiated between the city and the contractor, approved by the city council and reflected in the minutes of the city council. 
(c)  Persons occupying each single-family dwelling unit, each mobile home unit, and each unit of a duplex, townhouse, or apartment shall be subject to these guidelines for the collection of garbage and recyclable materials. Each residential unit will have one garbage pickup and one recycling pickup per week on the same day of the week. The pickup day is determined by the area in which the residence is located. 
(d)  Each business or each business unit within a business complex that does not subscribe to a dumpster service shall be subject to these guidelines and shall pay a required garbage fee based upon the amount of garbage generated weekly by said business. If a mobile home unit is located in a mobile home park or if an apartment unit is located in an apartment complex in which garbage collection fees are included in rental payments, payment of the collection fee shall be the responsibility of the mobile home park or apartment owner or management company. Each commercial unit will have garbage pickup two times per week on Monday and on Thursday. 
(e)  In weeks containing holidays that fall on a regularly scheduled waste pickup day, the garbage collection for that day will be delayed until the day following the holiday, and collection for succeeding days in that holiday week will be delayed by one day. The holidays observed by the Contractor are New Year's Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving, and Christmas. 
(Ord. No. 92-49 PW, § 1, 7-28-92; Ord. No. 2002-007-PW, § 1, 3-12-02) 
Sec. 74-57. - Waste collection. 
(a)  Residential units will use one 96-gallon garbage receptacle provided by the contractor. Special consideration will be given to those persons unable to use a 96-gallon receptacle due to age or infirmity. Either a 65-gallon receptacle or a 36-gallon receptacle will be provided by the contractor as a substitute for the 96-gallon receptacle dependant upon the individual needs; however, only one receptacle will be provided regardless of the size of the container provided. Persons requiring an additional receptacle may contract individually with the contractor. 
(b)  Residential units will receive a plastic bin provided by the contractor for the collection of recyclables to include newspaper, magazines, junk mail, white paper, cardboard, number one and two plastics, and aluminum, tin and bi-metal cans. 
(c)  The garbage receptacle and the recycling bin provided by the contractor for each residential unit are the property of the contractor and shall remain at the residential unit should the occupant move. 
(d)  Each apartment owner or management company shall pay a fee based upon the number of units at the rate per unit determined by the city council, where dumpster service is not provided by the lessor. Where dumpster service is not provided, one 96-gallon receptacle and one recycling bin shall be provided by the contractor for each unit. 
(e)  Each mobile home park owner or management company shall pay a fee quarterly based upon the number of units at the rate per unit determined by the city council, where dumpster service is not provided by the lessor. Where dumpster service is not provided, one 96-gallon receptacle and one recycling bin shall be provided by the contractor for each unit. 
(f)  Persons operating a place of business, whether business or professional office, store, shop, service station, restaurant, nursing home or other business where the city furnishes such collection service, and where not more than the capacity of one 96-gallon receptacle is generated twice per week shall pay a fee quarterly as determined by the city council. Commercial waste pickup is for garbage only and does not include recycling. The garbage receptacle provided by the contractor for each business unit is the property of the contractor and shall remain at the business unit should the occupant move. 
(g)  Persons operating a place of business, whether business or professional office, store, shop, service station, restaurant, nursing home or other business where the city furnishes such collection service, and where not more than the capacity of two 96-gallon receptacles is generated twice per week shall pay a fee quarterly as determined by the city council. Commercial waste pickup is for garbage only and does not include recycling. The garbage receptacle and the recycling bin provided by the contractor for each residential unit are the property of the contractor and shall remain at the residential [business] unit should the occupant move. 
(h)  Businesses generating more garbage than the capacity of two 96-gallon receptacles twice per week shall be required to arrange for disposal of waste by use of a dumpster or other disposal service approved by the city and/or other regulatory authority. 
(i)  Garbage receptacles and recycling bins shall be placed behind the curb or pavement edge for pickup. Garbage receptacles must be turned with the lid opening facing the street to facilitate the use of automated dumping equipment. 
(j)  Garbage that is not placed in the prescribed garbage receptacles will not be picked up. Recyclable materials that are oversized, such as cardboard boxes, may be collapsed and placed next to the recycling bin for pickup. Cardboard boxes filled with garbage, styrofoam, plastic, or other materials will not be picked up. 
(Ord. No. 92-49 PW, § 2, 7-28-92; Ord. No. 2002-007-PW, § 2, 3-12-02) 
Sec. 74-58. - Exceptions. 
    Persons who desire to be excepted from the provisions of this article and who desire to act as their own garbage contractor must apply for and be granted a certificate of exception by the Jefferson County Health Department and/or other regulatory authority. The certificate must be presented to the office of the city clerk for photocopying. All terms and conditions of the waste disposal permit must be met, as evidenced by periodic reports made to the city by the Jefferson County Health Department and/or other regulatory authority. 
(Ord. No. 92-49 PW, § 3, 7-28-92; Ord. No. 2002-007-PW, § 3, 3-12-02) 
Sec. 74-59. - Billing. 
(a)  Customer bills will be mailed the first week of each calendar quarter. Amounts for services rendered hereunder shall be due and payable upon receipt of the bill. 
(b)  If payment is not made to the city by the delinquency date printed on the bill, such payment shall be deemed delinquent and shall bear a late penalty of $5.00. 
(Ord. No. 92-49 PW, § 4, 7-28-92; Ord. No. 2002-007-PW, § 4, 3-12-02) 
Sec. 74-60. - Policy. 
(a)  The city shall be authorized to adopt, implement and revise policies, practices, rules and procedures as may be appropriate to promote the efficient administration of this article, subject, however, to the right of the city council to review and supersede such policies, practices, rules and procedures as may from time to time be required. 
(b)  The services and assessments provided herein shall be mandatory for all classes and categories described in this article. 
(Ord. No. 92-49 PW, § 5, 7-28-92; Ord. No. 2002-007-PW, § 5, 3-12-02) 
Chapter 78 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire chief may establish fire lanes, § 42-2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Street cutting permit. 
    A fee of $50.00 shall be charged for each street cutting permit issued. Each person filing application for a permit to cut a street in the city shall, before each permit is issued, furnish the city a certificate of current insurance or other form of security in a minimum amount of $2,500.00 applicable to the proposed work in the city. 
(Ord. No. 94-019 ADM, § 6, 4-12-94) 
Sec. 78-2. - Construction, installation procedure. 
    All utility lines, drainage structures, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, etc., which are to be installed under or along any existing road or street shall be installed as follows: 
(1)  All trenches shall be cut as narrow as practical for the installation and all ditching shall meet OSHA safety requirements. Pavement cuts shall be made with an abrasive saw or asphalt cutting wheel. 
(2)  After installation of the pipes, lines, etc., the trench shall be backfilled in layers not to exceed one foot in depth and compacted with a vibratory type compactor. 
(3)  Material for backfill shall be crushed stone (crusher run) under all paved areas to the outside of the gutter line. Native soil may be used for backfill outside of the gutter line, if approved by the engineering/inspections department of the city, but in no case shall crushed stone be required outside of the gutter line. 
(4)  The backfilling operation shall be observed by a city representative from the engineering/inspections department or his agent to verify that the proper backfilling procedure is followed. 
(5)  The top portion of any trench shall be constructed of: 
a.  A six-inch layer of crushed aggregate base compacted to 100 percent according to Alabama Highway Department 140 (Alabama Highway Department Specification 306.03e), using a vibratory type compactor. 
b.  A three-inch layer of bituminous concrete binder (AHD 414.02 mix B) properly compacted to AHD specifications 306.03g using a vibratory type compactor. 
c.  A layer of bituminous concrete wearing surface, matching the thickness of the existing street or road, according to Alabama Highway Department specification 416 mix A. Compaction shall be in accordance with Alabama Highway Department Specification 306.03g, using a vibratory type compactor. 
(6)  All work shall be completed, inspected and approved within a reasonable time so as not to present a traffic hazard in the paved areas. 
(7)  All workmanship shall meet the satisfaction of the city representative and shall present a neat and smooth surface. The final riding surface of the street over the repaired area shall not be appreciably different than before the area was disturbed. Any subsidence or defect that appears within a 12-month period shall be promptly repaired by the person responsible for making the installation. 
(8)  All new street construction shall meet the same requirements as installation under existing streets except the bituminous concrete pad as mentioned in subsection (5)b of this section is not required. 
(9)  The drawing on file in the building official's office shall serve to graphically represent items (1) through (6) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 91-34 PW, 9-24-91) 
Secs. 78-3-78-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 78-26. - Purpose and objectives. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to provide principles, procedures and associated funding for the placement of equipment and infrastructure, construction, and excavation encroachments and work activities within or upon any public rights-of-way and to protect the integrity of the road, utility and telecommunications systems. To achieve this purpose, it is necessary to require permits, to establish permit procedures and statements, and to fix and collect fees and charges. 
(b)  Objectives. It is recognized that there is a need to accommodate multiple entities in their provision of public services. However, the city must ensure that the primary purpose of the roadway, passage of vehicular traffic, is maintained to the greatest extent possible. The use of the roadway corridors (i.e., rights-of-way) by others is secondary to the movement of traffic. This article is intended to strike a balance between the public need for efficient, safe transportation routes and the use of the rights-of-way for location of equipment by public and private entities. This article thus has several objectives: 
(1)  To ensure that the public safety is maintained and that public inconvenience in minimized. 
(2)  To protect the city's infrastructure investment by establishing repair standards for all street improvements when work in the rights-of-way is undertaken. 
(3)  To facilitate work within the right-of-way through the standardization of regulations and hardware placements. 
(4)  To maintain an efficient permit process. 
(5)  To conserve the limited physical capacity of the public rights-of-way held in public trust by the city. 
(6)  To ensure that the city can continue to fairly and responsibly protect public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 1, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-27. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    City means the City of Trussville, Alabama. 
    Degradation means the accelerated depreciation of the right-of-way caused by excavation in or disturbance of the right-of-way, resulting in the need to reconstruct such right-of-way earlier than normal usage would require. 
    Director means the director of inspection services of the city's authorized representative. 
    Emergency means a condition that poses a clear and immediate danger to life or health, or of a significant loss of property, and work necessary to restore service as described in section 78-40 of this article. 
    Equipment means any tangible thing located in any right-of-way. 
    Fence means any artificially constructed barrier of wood, masonry, stone, wire, metal or any other manufactured material or combination of materials erected to enclose or screen areas of land. 
    Infrastructure means any public facility, system, or improvement including, without limitation, water and sewer mains and appurtenances, storm drains and structures, streets and sidewalks, and public safety equipment. 
    Landscaping means materials, including, without limitation, grass, ground cover, shrubs, vines, hedges, or trees, and non-living natural materials commonly used in landscaped development, as well as attendant irrigation systems. 
    Permittee means the holder of a valid permit issued pursuant to this article and includes, when the context so requires, an owner, developer, contractor and/or subcontractor. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, local government, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Public right-of-way means the surface and space above and below any public street, land, place, alley, sidewalk, easement, park, square, plaza, and any other public property owned or controlled by the city, and dedicated to public use. 
    Security means the cash, irrevocable letter of credit, or performance bond described in subsection 78-31(e) of this article. 
    Specifications means engineering regulations, construction specifications, and design standards adopted by the city. 
    Structure means anything constructed or erected with a fixed location below on, or above grade, including, without limitation, foundations, fences, retaining walls, awnings, balconies, and canopies. 
    Telecommunications facilities means communications lines or equipment of any kind, including, but not limited to, lines or equipment for the transmission of audio, video, or data, or other similar communication services, including all trunks, lines, cables, wires, optical fibers, or other fiber optic cables, laser equipment, circuits, physical connections, switching equipment, wireless communication equipment of all kinds, towers, and any necessary appurtenances owned, leased or operated by a person within the public right-of-way. 
    Utility facilities means the plant, equipment, and property, including, but not limited to, the poles, pipes, mains, conduits, ducts, cables, wires, plant and equipment located within the public right-of-way and used or intended to be used for the purpose of providing utility services. 
    Work in the public right-of-way means any labor performed on or any use or storage of equipment or materials in public rights-of-way including, but not limited to, construction of streets and all related appurtenances, sidewalks, driveway openings, bus shelters, bus loading pads, street lights, and traffic signal devices. It shall also mean construction, maintenance and repair of all underground telecommunications and/or utility facilities, or any other similar structure located below the surface of any public right-of-way, and installation of overhead poles used for any purpose. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 2, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-28. - Police powers. 
    The permittee's rights hereunder are subject to the police powers of the city, which include the power to adopt and enforce ordinances, including amendments to this article, necessary to the safety, health, and welfare of the public. The permittee shall comply with all applicable laws and ordinances enacted, or hereafter enacted, by the city or any other legally constituted governmental entity having lawful jurisdiction over the subject matter hereof. The city reserves the right to exercise its police powers, notwithstanding anything in this ordinance and the permit to the contrary. Any conflict between the provisions of this ordinance or the permit and any other present or fixture lawful exercise of the city's police powers shall be resolved in favor of the latter. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 3, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-29. - Permits. 
(a)  Permit required. No person except an employee or official of the city or a person under contract with the city shall undertake or permit to be undertaken any work in the public right-of-way without first obtaining a permit from the director as set forth in this section, except as provided in section 78-40. Each permit obtained, along with associated documents shall be maintained on the job site and available for inspection upon request by any officer or employee of the city. Annual permits shall be retained by the permittees at their designated local office or crew headquarters and shall be available for inspection upon request by any officer or employee of the city. 
(b)  Permit application. An applicant for a permit to allow work in the public right-of-way under this section, other than an annual permit as described in section 78-29(e), shall file a written application on forms furnished by the city that includes: 
(1)  The name, address, daytime telephone number, and name of a specific contact person with an emergency 24-hour per day telephone number for the applicant, developer, contractor, and/or subcontractor licensed to perform work in the public right-of-way; 
(2)  The exact location of the proposed work activity; 
(3)  The type of existing infrastructure (street pavement, curb and gutter, sidewalks or utilities) impacted by the work; 
(4)  The dates for beginning and ending of the proposed work; 
(5)  The type of work proposed including the measurements, quantities, itemization and total cost, including labor and materials. 
(c)  Additional application submittals. The permit application shall include the following additional information: 
(1)  Evidence that the applicant, its contractor, and subcontractor are not delinquent in any payments due the city on any prior work, for any reason; 
(2)  Evidence of all other permits or licenses (including required insurance, deposits, bonding and warranties) required to do the proposed work, if licenses or permits are required under the laws of the United States, the state, or the ordinances of the city; 
(3)  A satisfactory plan of work showing protection of the subject property and adjacent properties when the city determines such protection is necessary; 
(4)  A satisfactory plan for the protection of shade and ornamental trees and restoration of turf when the city determines that damage may occur to such trees or turf; 
(5)  Evidence that all orders issued by the city to the applicant, its contractor and subcontractors, requiring correction of deficiencies under previous permits issued pursuant to this article, have been satisfied; 
(6)  Engineering construction drawings or site plans for the proposed work; 
(7)  A satisfactory traffic control and erosion protection plan for the proposed work; 
(8)  Payment of the fees prescribed by this article. 
(d)  Permit contents. For the benefit of the city, each permit issued under this section will state: 
(1)  The right-of-way permit number; 
(2)  The date of permit issuance and expiration; 
(3)  The name and address of the permittee; 
(4)  The location, nature and purpose of the work in the right-of-way covered by the permit; 
(5)  Any conditions of approval, including but not limited to inspection, testing, certification, provision of as-built drawings; 
(6)  The type of existing infrastructure on the site at which the work will be undertaken; 
(7)  References for the engineering construction drawings or site plans; 
(8)  References to any supplemental permits required such as wetland, floodplain development, state highway access or utility water and sewer permits. 
(9)  The amount of fees paid and security filed by the permittee. 
(e)  Annual permit. Any public utility providing essential services, or regulated by the public service commission shall be eligible for an annual permit. The provisions of subsections (b), (c), (d), (h) and (i) shall not apply to annual permits. 
(1)  Permit application. The annual permit application shall include the following: 
a.  The applicant's name, address, daytime telephone number, and name of a specific contact person with an emergency 24-hour per day telephone number; 
b.  A general description of the categories of work to be performed under the permit; 
c.  An assurance that all of applicant's contractors and subcontractors will be required to comply with all applicable provisions of this and other city ordinances; 
d.  Evidence of all other permits or licenses (including required insurance, deposits, bonding and warranties) required to do the proposed work, if licenses or permits are required under the laws of the United States, the state, or the ordinances of the city; 
e.  Evidence that all orders issued by the city to the applicant, requiring correction of deficiencies under previous permits issued pursuant to this article, have been satisfied; 
(2)  Permit contents. For the benefit of the city, each annual permit will state: 
a.  The right-of-way permit number; 
b.  The date of permit issuance and expiration; 
c.  The name and address of the permittee; 
d.  A general description of the categories of work covered by the annual permit; 
e.  The amount of the initial permit fee paid and security filed by the permittee. 
(f)  Permit fee. Before a permit is issued, the applicant shall pay to the director a permit fee, which shall be determined in accordance with a fee schedule adopted by city council by resolution. Annual permittees, where suitable arrangements can be made, may be billed monthly or quarterly for permits issued. The permit fee shall be in an amount sufficient to recover the city's costs including, but not limited to, the administration of the permit process, inspection costs, and the degradation to the public right-of-way that will result from the proposed work, if the applicant is not proceeding to make the street surface repair by replacement of the entire excavated street surface segment between existing expansion joints. 
(g)  Permits nontransferable. Permits shall not be transferrable or assignable and work shall not be performed in any place other than that specified in the permit. The applicant may contract the work to be performed under a permit provided that the holder of the permit shall be and remain responsible for the performance of the work under the permit and all insurance and financial security as required. 
(h)  Mapping data. Each permittee shall provide to the director information indicating horizontal and vertical location, relative to the boundaries of the public right-of-way, of all equipment, telecommunications facilities and/or utility facilities located in any public right-of-way within the city limits. Information indicating existing equipment and facilities shall be provided within six months of the date of permit approval. Such information shall be updated upon completion of any work covered by a permit. The information shall be provided with the specificity and in the format requested by the director for inclusion in the mapping system used by the city. 
(i)  Each annual permittee shall provide to the city from time to time and upon the request of the city; such mapping data showing the general location of the permittees telecommunication facilities and utility facilities located in the public right-of-ways as may be reasonably provided. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 4, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-30. - Insurance and indemnification. 
(a)  Insurance. Before a permit is issued, the applicant shall file with the director an insurance policy or policies, or certificate(s) of coverage which include an endorsement placed on each policy requiring ten days notice by mail to the director before the insurer may cancel the policy for any reason, and additionally indicates that: 
(1)  The permittee maintains worker's compensation coverage as required by state law. 
(2)  The permittee maintains a comprehensive general liability policy, including broad form property damage, completed operations and contractual liability for limits not less than $3,000,000.00 for each occurrence for damages or bodily injury or death to one or more persons; and $1,000,000.00 for each occurrence for damage to or destruction of property. 
(3)  Insurance coverage for special hazards: special hazards coverage, such as but not limited to, property damage as a result of blasting, explosion hazard, collapse hazard, underground property damage hazard, commonly known as XCU, shall all be specifically added by endorsement to the hereinabove required liability policy. 
(b)  Self-insured entities. In lieu of filing proof of insurance as described in subsection (a), a self-insured entity may sign an acknowledgment in a form acceptable to the director indicating self-insured reserves sufficient to cover the same risks identified in subsection (a). 
(c)  Previous filing. Whenever any person has filed with the director evidence of insurance as required, any additional or subsequent permittee in the employ of the initial person shall not be required to file additional evidence of insurance, so long as the initial filing remains current. 
(d)  Indemnification. By acceptance of a permit, the permittee agrees to indemnify and hold the city harmless from all claims resulting from the permittee's actions or negligence, or other actions, demands, costs, expenses, damages, and liability arising from or related to permittee's work in the public right of way or the installation or maintenance of equipment therein, including costs of defense and attorneys fees. In the event that the permittee is a public entity, the indemnification requirements of this subsection shall be subject to the provisions of the Alabama Governmental Immunity Act. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 5, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-31. - Warranty guarantee. 
(a)  Purpose. The warranties made hereunder shall serve as security for the performance of work necessary to repair the public right-of-way if the permittee fails to make the necessary repairs or to complete the work under the permit. 
(b)  Permittee's warranty guarantee. The permittee, by acceptance of the permit, expressly warrants and guarantees complete performance of the work in a manner acceptable to the city, warrants and guarantees all work done for a period of two years after the date of acceptance, and agrees to maintain upon demand and to make all necessary repairs during the two-year period. The warranty shall include all repairs and actions needed as a result of: 
(1)  Defects in workmanship; 
(2)  Settling of fills or excavations; 
(3)  Any unauthorized deviations from the approved plans and specifications: 
(4)  Failure to barricade; 
(5)  Failure to clean up during and after performance of the work; 
(6)  Any other violation of this or any other ordinances of the city. 
(c)  Repairs during warranty period. The two-year warranty period shall run from the date of the city's acceptance of the work. If repairs are required during the two-year warranty period, those repairs need only be warranted until the end of the initial two-year period starting with the date of initial acceptance. It is not necessary that a new two-year warranty be provided for subsequent repairs after initial acceptance. 
(d)  Time to complete repairs. At any time prior to completion of the warranty period, the city may notify the permittee of any needed repairs. Such repairs shall be completed within 24 hours if the defects are determined by the city to create an emergency condition as defined by this article. Non-emergency repairs shall be completed within 30 days after notice. 
(e)  Security. Each permittee, before being issued a permit, shall provide the city, at the permittee's expense, security for the warranty guarantee in the form of cash, an irrevocable letter of credit or performance bond. 
(1)  The security shall be in an amount equal to 100 percent of the city's estimate of the cost of restoration. The cost of restoration shall include, without limitation, the removal of defective material, recompaction of subgrade and base material, and construction of surface improvements. 
(2)  The city may waive the warranty guarantee and security requirements for any owner of a single-family residence desiring to repair their driveway or sidewalk, provided the owner performs the work personally, and upon satisfactory evidence to the city that the owner is competent to perform the work. 
(3)  Any performance bond provided as security shall be executed by the permittee as principal and by at least one surety upon whom service of process may be had in this state. The bond must be approved by the city clerk as to form and as to the responsibility of the surety thereon prior to the issuance of the permit. 
(4)  The security shall remain in effect throughout the entire time that permittee's warranty guarantee is in effect for any work covered by this article. 
(f)  Exceptions to security requirement. 
(1)  In lieu of the security requirement described in subsection (e), persons holding a franchise with the city, or any governmental entity, may provide the city with an annual letter signed by an appropriate authorized official guaranteeing: 
a.  Complete performance of the work acceptable to the city; and 
b.  Correction of any defect in the work which the city discovers and for which the city gives written notice to the permittee within two years after the date when the city initially accepts the work. 
c.  If the city determines that any permittee fails to promptly perform under the conditions of this subsection, that permittee shall be required to post security meeting the requirements of subsection (e). If the city determines that the permittee then satisfactorily complies with all provisions of this section 78-31 for a period of two years, the permittee shall then again be eligible to operate with the annual guarantee letter provided for herein. 
(3)  Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, any contractor performing work pursuant to a contract directly with the city shall adhere to the performance payment requirements set forth in the contract documents. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 6, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-32. - Inspections. 
(a)  Permits under subsection 78-29(d). For any permits issued under subsection 78-29(d), two inspections shall take place. First, the permittee shall notify the city immediately after completion of the work operations, and acceptance will be made if all work meets city standards. Second, approximately 30 days prior to the expiration of the two-year guarantee, the city shall perform an inspection of the completed work. If the completed work is still satisfactory, the security shall be returned less any amounts needed to complete work not done by permittee. For permittees with other ongoing work permitted or still under warranty pursuant to this article, a notation shall be made on the permit documents indicating that the warranty period has been completed and the work remained satisfactory. 
(b)  Permits under subsection 78-29(e). For any permits involving new construction (excluding preventive and routine maintenance and routine repairs) issued under subsection 78-29(e), two inspections shall take place. First, the permittee shall notify the city by the tenth day of each month of the completion of the work operations during the preceding calendar month. Acceptance will be made if all work meets city standards. Second, approximately 30 days prior to the expiration of the two-year guarantee, the city shall perform an inspection of the completed work. If the completed work is still satisfactory, the security shall be returned less any amounts needed to complete work not done by permittee. For permittees with other ongoing work permitted or still under warranty pursuant to this article, a notation shall be made on the permit documents indicating that the warranty period has been completed and the work remained satisfactory. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 7, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-33. - Public safety and nuisance. 
    Any permittee shall maintain a safe work area, free of nuisance conditions. The city may make any repair necessary to eliminate any emergency condition, hazard or nuisance or work not performed as directed. Any such work performed by the city shall be completed and billed to the permittee at overtime rates. The permittee shall pay all such charges within 30 days of the statement date. If the permittee fails to pay such charges within the prescribed time period, the city may, in addition to taking other collection remedies, seek reimbursement through the security. Furthermore, the permittee shall be barred from performing any work in the public right-of-way, and under no circumstances will the city issue any further permits of any kind to said permittee until such time as all outstanding charges have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 8, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-34. - Time of completion. 
    All work covered by the permit shall be completed by the date stated on the application. Permits shall be void if work has not commenced six months after issuance. Security deposited with the city will be returned after voiding of a permit. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 9, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-35. - Traffic control. 
(a)  Traffic obstructions. 
(1)  No permittee should block emergency vehicles, block access to fire hydrants, fire stations, fire escapes, water valves, underground valves, valve housing structures, or any vital equipment. 
(2)  If a street closing is desired, the permittee must obtain the prior written permission of the director. Permittee shall comply with the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) adopted by the State Highway Department on road closures as it may exist at the time of the permit, which presently includes two-week advance notice of the road closure posted on-site and published in the local newspaper. No permit will be issued until the plan is approved by the director. 
(3)  When it is necessary to block traffic for more than one hour on arterial or collector streets or more than six hours on other streets, a detour plan shall be submitted to the city prior to starting construction. No permit will be issued until the plan is approved by the director 
(4)  It shall be the responsibility of the permittee to notify and coordinate all work in the public right-of-way with police, fire, ambulance, transit organizations, schools and trash pickup service. 
(5)  The blocking of traffic for no more than one hour on arterial or collector streets, no more than six hours on other streets, or for emergency purposes as described in section 78-40 of this article, shall not be subject to the provisions of subsections (2), (3), and (4); provided, however, that any blocking of any street in excess of one hour shall require prior notification to the city police and fire department. 
(b)  Use of flag persons. When necessary for public safety, the permittee shall employ flag persons whose duty shall be to control traffic around or through the construction site. These flag persons may be required by the director. 
(c)  Rush hour traffic. Unless approved by the director, the permittee shall not impede rush hour traffic on arterial or collector streets during the morning or evening rush hours. No construction shall be performed nor shall any traffic lane be closed to traffic during the hours of 6:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m., and 4:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. without the written approval of the director. 
(d)  Traffic control devices. Traffic control devices, as defined in Part VI of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, must be used whenever it is necessary to close a traffic lane or sidewalk. Traffic control devices are to be supplied by the permittee. If used at night, they must be reflectorized and must be illuminated or have barricade warning lights. Oil flares or kerosene lanterns are not allowed as a means of illumination. Part VI of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices shall be used as a guide for all maintenance and construction signing. The permittee shall illustrate on the permit the warning and control devices proposed for use. At the direction of the director, such warning and control devices shall be increased, decreased, or modified. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 10, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-36. - Minimizing the impacts of work in the public right-of-way. 
(a)  Relocation and protection of utilities. Before any permittee begins excavation in any public right-of-way, he shall contact the Alabama Line Location Center, Inc. (252-4444; 1-800-292-8525), and make inquiries of all utility companies, municipal and other governmental departments, and all other agencies that might have facilities in the area of work to determine possible conflicts. The permittee shall contact the Alabama Line Location Center, Inc. and request field locations of all facilities in the area at least 48 hours in advance. Except in emergencies, field location shall be marked prior to commencing excavation work. The permittee shall support and protect all equipment, telecommunications facilities and utility facilities which may be affected by the work from damage during construction or settlement of trenches subsequent to construction. 
(b)  Noise, dust, debris, and hours of work. Each permittee shall conduct work in such manner as to avoid unnecessary inconvenience and annoyance to the general public and occupants of neighboring property. In the performance of the work, the permittee shall take appropriate measures to reduce noise between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., and to reduce dust, and unsightly debris. No work in any residential area shall be done at any time on Sunday, except with the written permission of the director, or in case of an emergency or other out of service conditions. 
(c)  Trash and construction materials. Each permittee shall maintain the work site so that: 
(1)  Trash and construction materials are contained so that they are not blown off the construction site; 
(2)  Trash is removed from the construction-site often enough so that it does not become a health, fire or safety hazard; and 
(3)  Trash dumpsters and storage or construction trailers are not placed in streets without specific approval of the director. 
(d)  Deposit of dirt and materials on roadways. Each permittee shall take reasonable steps to minimize the tracking of mud or debris upon any street or sidewalk. Permittee will take all steps necessary to comply with city regulations or ordinances concerning streets or roadways. 
(e)  Protection of trees and landscaping. Each permittee should protect trees, landscape, and landscape features as the extent practicable. All protective measures shall be provided at the expense of the permittee. This provision in no way precludes normal tree trimming maintenance required for reliable operations of aerial facilities. 
(f)  Protection of paved surfaces from equipment damage. Backhoe equipment outriggers shall be fitted with rubber pads whenever outriggers are placed on any paved surface. Track vehicles with trousers are not permitted on paved surface unless specific precautions are taken to protect the surface. The permittee will be responsible for any damage caused to the pavement or other street improvements by the operation of such equipment and, upon order of the director, shall repair such surfaces. Failure to do so will result in the use of permittee's security by the city to repair any damage. 
(g)  Protection of property. Each permittee shall protect from injury any adjoining property by providing adequate support and taking other necessary measures. The permittee shall, at its own expense, shore up and protect all buildings, walls, fences, or other property likely to be damaged during the work, and shall be responsible for all damage to public and private property resulting from failure to properly protect and carry out work in the public way. 
(h)  Cleanup. As the work progresses, all public rights-of-way and private property shall be thoroughly cleaned of all rubbish, excess dirt, rock and other debris. All clean up operations shall be done at the expense of the permittee. 
(i)  Preservation of monuments. Each permittee shall not disturb any surface monuments or survey hubs and points found on the line of work unless approval is obtained from the director. Any monuments, hubs and points disturbed will be replaced by a state registered land surveyor at the permittee's expense. 
(j)  Parking. Each permittee shall make provisions for employee and construction vehicle parking so that neighborhood parking adjacent to a work site is not impacted. 
(k)  Walkways. Each permittee shall maintain an adequate and safe unobstructed walkway around a construction site or blocked sidewalk. 
(l)  Open trenching. No trench shall remain open without active, on-going work for a period in excess of 72 consecutive hours. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 11, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-37. - Standards for repairs. 
(a)  Permittee responsibility. The permittee shall be fully responsible for the cost and actual performance of all work in the public right-of-way. The permittee shall do all work in conformance with any and all engineering regulations, construction specifications, and design standards adopted by the city. Any such standards adopted by the city shall apply to all work in the public right-of-way unless otherwise indicated in the permit. 
(b)  Specific standards relating to work in the public right-of-way. All final restoration of the worksite shall result in a work site condition at least equal to that which existed prior to construction, to the extent practicable. In addition to the regulations, specifications and standards referred to in subsection (a), the following provisions shall apply to all work in the public right-of-way within the city: 
(1)  Pavement cuts shall be filled with compacted select material. Either concrete or asphalt patches will be placed to match the existing street cross section. Select material shall include select fill, stone or controlled density (flowable) fill. 
(2)  For pavement cuts, select fill shall be placed in an excavation in eight-inch lifts and compacted with a vibratory plate compactor (for small openings), jumping jack (alongside pipelines), or with a static roller (for large openings). Compaction by backhoe bucket is never acceptable. In cases where groundwater is present, stone shall be substituted for select fill. 
(3)  In cases where it is impossible to achieve required compaction of 20 CBR on select fill, the city encourages the use of controlled density fill material. When controlled density fill type material is used, steel plate will be placed to cover the opening for the time required to allow the material to set. The controlled density fill material shall be course sand or fine, one-quarter inch limestone, or equivalent. 
(4)  Once the compacted backfill has been placed, an asphalt cutback shall be made. The cutback will extend six inches minimum on each side of the opening and will be over undisturbed pavement material (one and one-half-inch deep minimum). All edges of the opening shall be neatly cut with an asphalt saw and uniformly tact. A temporary patch shall be placed for a period of 15 to 30 days to allow settlement of fill materials. 
(5)  After the settlement period described in subsection (b)(4), the new asphalt will be placed in lifts (three-inch maximum) and compacted upon placement. Asphalt depths will be governed by the existing cross section of the street but not less than four inches of full deep asphalt shall be used to fill a street cut regardless of the existing cross section. Concrete shall be used to replace concrete pavement wherever it occurs. 
(6)  Damage to curbs, gutters, sidewalks, and inlets shall be repaired so as to comply with any applicable subdivision regulations. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 12, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-38. - Construction and restoration standards for newly constructed or overlayed streets. 
(a)  Application required. As a result of the degradation to newly constructed or overlayed streets caused by excavation, no person shall excavate an area in the pavement of any public right-of-way for a period of five years from the completion of construction or resurfacing except in compliance with the provision of this section. (Persons holding permits issued under subsection 78-29(e) shall not be required to obtain a permit under this section 78-38) Any application for a permit to work in a public right-of-way subject to the requirements of this section shall contain the following information: 
(1)  A detailed and dimensional engineering plan that identifies and accurately represents the public right-of-way or property that will be impacted by the proposed excavation, as well as the side streets at the end of each city block that may be impacted. The following information shall also be included on the plan: 
a.  The street width including curb and gutter over the total length of each city block that will be impacted by the proposed excavation. 
b.  The location, width and depth of the proposed excavation. 
c.  The total area of existing pavement in each individual city block that will be impacted by the proposed excavation. 
(2)  A written statement addressing the criteria for approval. 
(b)  Criteria for approval. No permit for excavation in a right-of-way of new streets shall be approved unless the director finds that all of the following criteria have been met: 
(1)  Boring or jacking under the pavement is not practical due to physical characteristics of the right-of-way or other utility conflicts. 
(2)  Alternative utility alignments that do not involve excavating within the right-of-way are found to be impracticable. 
(3)  The proposed excavation cannot reasonably be delayed until after the five-year deferment period has lapsed. 
(c)  Exemptions for emergency operations. Emergency maintenance operation shall be limited to circumstances involving the preservation of life, property, or the restoration of customer utility service. Persons with prior authorization from the city, or authorized under section 78-40, to perform emergency maintenance operations within the public right-of-way shall be exempted from this subsection. Any person commencing operations pursuant to this subsection shall submit detailed engineering plans and remediation plans no later than five working days after initiating the emergency maintenance operation. 
(d)  Construction and restoration standards for newly constructed or overlayed portions of public rights-of-way. The public right-of-way shall be repaired so as not to reduce the useful life of the pavement in accordance with design and construction standards adopted by the city. If the total area of the proposed excavation exceeds 15 percent of the total area of pavement within a block or involves a trench in excess of 150 feet in length, the applicant shall remediate the damage caused to the pavement. Remediation will consist of a curb to curb profile and overlay, a centerlined curb profile and overlay, or a lane line to curb profile and overlay, whichever is necessary in order not to decrease the average life expectancy of the right-of-way surface. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 13, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-39. - Relocation of facilities. 
    If at any time the city requests the permittee to relocate its equipment, telecommunications facilities or utility facilities, in order to allow the city to make any public use of the right-of-way, or if at any time it shall become necessary for any purpose to improve, repair, construct or maintain any public right-of-way, or for reasons of traffic conditions, public safety, or reason of installation of any type of structure of public improvement, to move or change the permittee's facilities within or adjacent to streets or public right-of-way in any manner, either temporarily or permanently, the city shall notify the permittee, at least 90 days in advance, except in the case of emergencies, of the city's intention to perform or have such work performed. The permittee shall thereupon, at its sole cost and expense, accomplish the necessary relocation, removal or change within a reasonable time from the date of the notification, but in no event later than three working days prior to the date the city has notified the permittee that it intends to commence its work or immediately in the case of emergencies. Upon the permittee's failure to accomplish such work, the city or other public agency, may perform such work at the permittee's expense, and the permittee shall reimburse the city or other agency within 30 days after receipt of a written invoice. Following the relocation, all affected property shall be restored to, at a minimum, the condition which existed prior to construction, at the permittee's expense. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 14, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-40. - Emergency procedures. 
    Any person maintaining equipment, telecommunications facilities or utility facilities in the public right-of-way may proceed with repairs upon existing facilities without a permit when emergency circumstances demand that the work be done immediately. Work necessary to restore water, sewer, gas, electric, telephone, and cable television facilities is considered emergency work. Repairs on other facilities in the public rights-of-way may also be administratively classified as emergency work by the director. Unless the person doing the work holds an annual permit issued under subsection 78-29(e), he or she shall apply to the city for a permit on the first working day after such work has commenced. All emergency work which will block traffic for more than one hour on any street will require prior telephone notification to the city police department and fire department. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 15, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-41. - Revocation of permits. 
(a)  Grounds. Any permit may be revoked or suspended by the director, after notice to the permittee for: 
(1)  Violation of any condition of the permit or of any provision of this article. 
(2)  Violation of any provision of any other ordinance of the city, state or federal law relating to the work. 
(3)  Existence of any condition or performance of any act which constitutes or causes a condition endangering life or damage to property. 
A suspension or revocation by the director, and a stop work order shall take effect immediately upon notice to the person performing the work in the public right-of-way. 
(b)  Stop work order. A stop work order may be issued by the director to any person or persons doing or causing any work to be done in the public right-of-way without a permit, or in violation of any provision of this article, or of any other ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 16, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-42. - Appeals procedure. 
    Any decision rendered by the director may be appealed within 30 days by the permittee to the board of zoning adjustments in accordance with the rules and procedures established by that body. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 17, 5-27-97) 
Sec. 78-43. - Penalties. 
(a)  If any person, firm or corporation, including but not limited to the officers and agents of a corporation responsible for its actions or inactions, and the partners of a partnership, firm or joint venture, shall violate or cause the violation of any of the provisions of this article, they shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which a violation is committed, continues or is permitted. Upon conviction of any such violation such person, firm or corporation, including but not limited to such partners, officers or agents, shall be punished as provided in article III, section 1.7, as amended, of the Trussville Municipal Code for each such violation. 
(b)  Non-exclusive remedy. The remedies provided in this article are not exclusive or in lieu of other rights and remedies that the city may have at law or in equity. The city is hereby authorized to seek legal and equitable relief for actual or threatened injury to the public rights-of-way, including damages to the rights-of-way, whether or not caused by a violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-012 ADM, § 18, 5-27-97)

ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Property taxes generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-51-1 et seq. 

Sec. 82-31. - City tax year; due date. 
    It is hereby fixed and provided that the tax year for the city shall commence on October 1 of each year and end on the next succeeding September 30, and that on and after October 1 municipal taxes in the city shall be based and due on state and county assessments for the preceding tax year, and shall be due and delinquent at the time when the state and county taxes for the preceding year are due and delinquent. 
(Ord. No. 88-3 ADM, § 1, 11-22-88) 
Sec. 82-32. - Levy. 
    There is levied for each municipal tax year ad valorem taxes on all real estate and personal property and intangibles situated within the corporate limits of the city and which is subject to municipal ad valorem taxes by the city under the constitution and laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 88-3 ADM, § 2, 11-22-88) 
Sec. 82-33. - Annual rate. 
    There is hereby levied upon all property and subjects of taxation liable thereof within the corporate limits of the city for the tax year beginning October 1, 2014, and for each succeeding ad valorem tax year: 
(1)  A general municipal tax of one-half of one per centum (that is, five mills on each dollar or $0.50 per $100.00) on the value of all taxable property situated within the corporate limits of the city, as assessed for state taxation as shown on the books of assessment for the preceding state and county tax year; the proceeds of such tax to be used for any purpose for which the city may lawfully expend funds; and 
(2)  A special municipal tax of seven-tenths of one per centum (that is, seven mills on each dollar or $0.70 per $100.00) on the value of all taxable property situated within the corporate limits of the city, as assessed for state taxation as shown on the books of assessment for the preceding state and county tax year; the proceeds of such tax to be used only for new construction, renovations, additions, and operations of the public schools in the city (said tax being authorized at an election held in the city on February 25, 2014). 
(Ord. No. 88-3 ADM, § 3, 11-22-88; Ord. No. 2014-005-ADM, § 1, 4-22-14) 
Sec. 82-34. - Collection by county; commission. 
    The tax assessor and tax collector of the county are hereby authorized, directed and empowered to assess and collect municipal taxes as provided in this article, and the tax assessor shall receive as commission the sum of two percent for assessing the taxes, as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 88-3 ADM, § 4, 11-22-88) 
State Law reference- Optional method for ad valorem taxes, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-51-40 et seq. 
Secs. 82-35-82-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALES AND USE TAX[3] 
Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
